DEBATE.TITLE:
RETIREMENT SAVINGS ACCOUNTS BILL 1996 Cognate bills: RETIREMENT SAVINGS ACCOUNTS (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1996
RETIREMENT SAVINGS ACCOUNTS SUPERVISORY LEVY BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilton, Greg, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Those in the House who have been paying attention to the debate on the Retirement Savings Accounts Bill would know that the opposition is not seeking to oppose this bill. However, we do have several concerns which will be reflected in the amendments we are seeking to move. We trust that our concerns will also be addressed within the parameters of the processes of Senate scrutiny.

SPEECH.PARA: I begin my submission by saying that Labor not only allowed banks to enter Australia's growing superannuation market but also oversaw perhaps one of its greatest success stories—the introduction of compulsory superannuation. The growth of industry schemes, as part of the union arranged superannuation arrangements, has also met with great success. Many workers in the country have reaped significant benefits from union based, industry based funds which have performed very well.

That contrasts somewhat with the introduction of retirement savings accounts by the coalition, which is being driven, at least in part, by their suspicion and mistrust of the aforementioned industry based superannuation funds—primarily because of the involvement of trade unions and workers as trustees on the boards of these funds—and by the fact that they need to pay back the banks all those generous donations they made to the coalition prior to the last election. Of course, it is well known to us on this side that the ANZ was the largest net donor to the coalition of any corporation in the country.

It is also the contention of the opposition that, given those on the other side constantly cry for the need to foster and promote competition, the government should let superannuation funds offer RSAs as well. Under the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act, equal representation on the board of trustees of superannuation funds of both employers and employees is guaranteed—that is to say, there is equal representational numbers of each party, and, quite rightly, a two-thirds majority of the board is required before any decision is taken and acted upon. This structure obviously ensures that the interests of everyone, both parties, are addressed and guaranteed. This has proved to be a remarkably effective and efficient system.

I am aware of many industry superannuation funds which could serve as a model for cooperation between employers and, in particular, trade unions at any level. I could cite, for example, my recent conversation with Mr Graham Gathercole, who is the Managing Director of Gathercole's Abattoirs, in the electorate of Isaacs. He is a trustee of the Meat Industry Superannuation Fund. I have also been privileged to be a member of the Labour Union Cooperative Retirement Fund myself. They are two of the best performing funds around. Those two funds are fine examples of the cooperation of union-employer trustee arrangements.

One of the main differences between an RSA and a traditional superannuation fund is that, unlike superannuation funds, which do have a trustee structure and whose trustees can be charged under the Corporations Act for any misdemeanours they might commit—because, obviously, they hold money on behalf of their members and are not profit making bodies—RSAs will have no such trustee structure. Hence, those safeguards have been swept aside and will just disappear.

There is no doubt that banks simply see RSAs as a way to lock in long-term capital in a low interest type product. Of course, we all know now that RSAs will be capital guaranteed. But it is vitally important that investors in RSAs understand exactly what it means to be capital guaranteed.

Firstly, the capital guarantee simply means that the amount invested cannot be reduced due to negative instrument returns or through the imposition of fees. The upshot of this is that with this level of security goes the acknowledgment from both the government and the banks that the rate of return on RSAs will be something around three per cent lower than that for superannuation funds. Indeed, in his submission to the House earlier today, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and shadow Treasurer (Mr Gareth Evans) cited Australian Consumers Association evidence of that three per cent figure. It is due to this low rate of return that there has been a push to set a maximum limit on RSAs of around $10,000, at which point investors would need to replace any further funds in a traditional account to attract higher returns.

Secondly, the capital guarantee does not mean that, in the case of a bank collapsing or facing some form of liquidity difficulties, investors may be safeguarded. The low return rates of RSAs are a concern not just to individual investors but because of the effect that they will have on the national saving pool and on a retiree's ability to provide for themselves in their retirement.

One turns to the elderly when one thinks of the fact that the banks no doubt, with the government's compliance, will be marketing RSAs at retirees and the elderly, given that retirees are looking at some form of safe place in which to invest their money with low risk. But what is not being marketed or what I do not foresee will be marketed to these retirees is the fact that these RSAs will also have low rates of return. In fact, retirees and the elderly could quite alternatively and simply deposit their money into other capital guaranteed funds which are similarly of low risk but which offer higher rates of return.

I have cited the fact that the Australian Consumers Association has taken an interest in this area and has provided us with a further glaring example of the differences in performances between outcomes of RSAs and superannuation funds. In fact, the association compared three people—an example cited by the member for Holt—who have $10,000 to invest. One person leaves it in an RSA for the rest of their working life, attracts a real interest rate of one per cent and comes out at the end with a lump sum of around $164,000. The second person leaves his or her investment in a superannuation fund, earns a real return of some four per cent and gets a pay-out of $225,000. The third person gets a return of perhaps 6.5 per cent from their superannuation fund and ends up with $390,000. So, as you can see, there is a massive difference in their performances, one which will no doubt have a potentially significant impact on both national savings and the government's social security commitments.

It must be drawn to the attention of potential investors again that, while these RSAs might be low cost, while they might be low risk, they are of low rate of return. That needs to be spelt out by the federal government and the banks. Choice is a great thing, but people must be given and afforded the opportunity of digesting all the relevant information before they are able to make what is hopefully an informed choice.

The government has been very keen to have the whole arena of superannuation withdrawn from industrial awards, which generally prescribe which industry superannuation fund employees and employers will contribute to. The government has argued that this limits choice and, hence, competition amongst suppliers of superannuation and related product instruments. No doubt we will see further efforts and further examples to have the Workplace Relations Act amended to exclude similar superannuation provisions.

One interesting advantage that the current proposed RSA system does have is that it does require far less time and effort administratively from employers than would a system which would see every employee having a different superannuation fund or RSA. Given the fact that the government has indeed made great play of reducing the amount of red tape on business, this is a point that they seem to have conveniently overlooked.

How much choice there will be in reality, unless RSAs are functioning properly, is anyone's guess. How much choice there will be, unless the advantages and disadvantages of the system are fully explained, is again anyone's guess. These things need to be properly explained by the banks and by those offering RSAs. The government has not given any indication that it has thought through this task.

RSA providers are not required to disclose information to employees before an RSA account is opened. What should be the employee's choice? Should they open an account? If so, with whom? These are the sorts of choices that ought to be made by the person whose money is being deposited and they ought to be made with the benefit of being afforded all proper information.

How much choice will there really be in the workplace when a boss says to their new employee that he or she would prefer them to take out an RSA with a given bank? The choice may be to take an RSA with a particular bank or perhaps forgo their job—an unlikely example perhaps but far from impossible. Even a 14‐day cooling-off period, as proposed under the legislation, in my view, would do little to address this potentially problematic scenario.

I have said before on more than one occasion that RSAs are of low growth and a low return product. Something that really has never been acknowledged by the Treasurer is the fact that they are a low return product. Employees must understand the long-term cost of remaining within a retirement savings account as opposed to remaining in the long haul with a managed superannuation fund. I cite again that, according to data recently published by the Australian Consumers Association, rates of return average something around three per cent below those of managed superannuation funds, and it is indeed essen tial that prospective consumers of this superannuation instrument comprehend this.

Furthermore, if the government really does believe in choice and competition, why will it not allow superannuation funds to operate RSAs? I contend that it is because the government has a fundamental loathing of superannuation funds which have union involvement. Or perhaps it is because this might result in a little bit too much competition for the banks. I have no doubt that the Wallis inquiry will recommend further mergers of banks, or at least not oppose further mergers of banks. Again, one wonders what the government's position would be on that particular matter, given that it would serve to decrease levels of competition—something that I would have thought the government was trying to foster.

Another important distinction between RSAs and superannuation funds is that many funds are in the practice of offering death and disability insurance as part of their overall benefit package. For many low income earning Australians, this is a service they would not otherwise be able to avail themselves of. RSAs are unlikely to offer such services or, indeed, if they did, it would be at prohibitive cost. For low income earners, RSAs do not offer the same type of superannuation cover as do superannuation funds.

Of course, the government will also argue that the introduction of RSAs will solve the problems associated with small accounts. These accounts have in the past been heavily eaten into by administrative fees and charges, often resulting in negative returns. However, the introduction in 1995 of the Small Superannuation Accounts Act, which provides the Australian Taxation Office the opportunity to operate small accounts in such a way as to ensure that both fees and charges do not exceed earnings, has done much to address this problem.

To conclude, I outline the concerns of the opposition. There is no trustee structure within the RSA arrangements. The possibilities of informed choice are diminished concomitantly with a possible rise in coercion in terms of which fund an employee is directed at by his or her employer. As I have said before in my submission, we are also con cerned about the low rates of return, and that bogie of the government, the ACTU, of course, shares these concerns but would support the amendments the opposition is seeking to make. The opposition is to vote in support of these bills but will be looking to the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation to investigate these possible amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hockey, Joe, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Over the past five to 10 years there has been much discussion of the so-called greying of Australia. In 1901, only four per cent of the population of Australia was 65 or over. By 1961, the proportion of the population aged over 65 had more than doubled to 8.5 per cent. Today it is estimated to be approximately 13 per cent. In my electorate of North Sydney, according to the 1991 census, the proportion of the population aged 65 or more was slightly greater than the national average.

SPEECH.PARA: It is anticipated that the ageing of the Australian population will continue, experiencing marked growth at the turn of the century and particularly after 2011. By 2030, close to 20 per cent of the Australian population will be 65 or over. By 2051, it will be one-third.

While our ageing trend appears dramatic, it has not proceeded to the same degree as many other industrialised countries, particularly those in northern Europe. For example, in 1985 Norway and Sweden already had a greater proportion of persons over 65 than Australia expects to reach at the turn of the century. This is due in large part to the fact that Australia has sustained fairly high levels of immigration since World War II. The population ageing which has characterised Australia's demographic outlook is in part due to increased longevity; however, it is more significantly due to the fact that the baby boom was followed by a dramatic decline in the birth rate.

Coinciding with this increase in the population of older Australians is the tendency for the age of retirement to actually decrease. In the 30-year period between 1966 and 1996, the labour force participation of people aged 55 and older fell from 33 per cent to 22 per cent. The trend towards earlier retirement, coupled with increased life expectancy, has prompted some to refer to retirement as a separate or third age, one almost as long as the working or second age. Indeed, today the period of economic dependency on the age pension or one's own savings, as the case may be, is often lengthy; 20 to 30 years is not uncommon for those retiring at the age of 55.

It is interesting to note that the concept of retirement of any sort is a 20th century concept. The concept of a lengthy period of retirement is very modern. Prior to the Industrial Revolution, most individuals simply worked until they were physically unable to do so, at which time their families became the providers of support and care. Most people were self‐employed in agriculture or small businesses. Furthermore, far fewer people lived to an advanced age.

The Australian age pension can trace its origins to the early years of this century and, in large part, is a result of the depression of the 1890s. Australia, despite its youth, was well ahead of the United States and Canada in this regard as the US did not introduce such a system until the 1930s and Canada did not introduce it until the 1920s. The institution of retirement gradually evolved through this century, but it was not until the mid‐1970s that Australia experienced rapid rates of retirement. Coincidentally, this came at the same time as the end of full employment.

Australia's demographic outlook and the trend towards early retirement require government policies that facilitate the way in which people can make greater provision for their retirement during their working lives. Recognising that superannuation policy is central to coping with an ageing population and is an important vehicle for national savings, this government has undertaken a number of important and significant initiatives to make superannuation a fairer and more flexible retirement system for all Australians. Specifically, firstly, the government is meeting its election commitment to introduce a rebate of 18 per cent from 1 July 1997 for individuals who make contributions on behalf of spouses with low incomes. Secondly, the government will increase the general age limit for superannuation contributions from 65 to 70. Third ly, the government will allow employees with incomes between $450 and $900 a month to choose between superannuation guarantee contributions or the equivalent as wages or salary.

For those families running a small business, the government is introducing its promised capital gains exemption on the sale of small businesses where the proceeds are used for retirement purposes. This exemption will operate in a manner consistent with the announcement in the budget to provide capital gains tax rollover relief for small businesses. Finally, the government intends to allow banks, building societies, credit unions and life insurance companies to provide superannuation without a trust structure in the form of retirement savings accounts, also known as RSAs, through the implementation of the Retirement Savings Account Bill 1996, which is what we are discussing today.

Retirement savings accounts are a simple, low cost, low risk investment product especially suited to those with small amounts of superannuation, such as itinerant or casual workers, those wishing to amalgamate small amounts of superannuation and those nearing retirement who may wish to minimise risk.

This bill forms part of a package of three bills that serve to implement the government's 1996 budget decision regarding retirement savings accounts—the RSAs. The government believes that retirement savings accounts play an important role in increasing choice in superannuation by giving employees greater scope to control the investment of their superannuation savings. Retirement savings accounts also play an important role in increasing competition by, firstly, raising the standard of service in the delivery in the superannuation industry; secondly, encouraging greater product innovation and diversity; and, thirdly, placing downward pressure on fees and charges.

Existing legislation requires a trustee structure as a condition to receiving concessional tax treatment. This bill, however, allows specified prudentially supervised institutions—that is, banks, building societies, credit unions and life insurance companies—to provide superannuation in the form of RSAs without a trust structure from 1 July 1997. Through the government's RSA reforms, these institutions will be able to provide superannuation directly off their balance sheet, facilitating more cost‐efficient delivery of superannuation without compromising the security of member benefits.

Of course, it is not the intent of the government that RSAs replace existing superannuation funds. Rather, it is intended that the availability of RSAs will expand the range of options for consumers. The provision of retirement savings accounts will benefit employees who have broken work patterns, as RSAs will offer a flexible product to accommodate small and irregular contributions. RSAs will benefit the approximately two million Australians, or around 22 per cent of the total work force, who are involved in part‐time employment, many of whom work with a number of different employers. RSAs will benefit the approximately 15,000 North Sydney citizens who are employed on a part‐time basis.

RSAs will be of particular benefit to women who stop work or work on a part‐time or part‐year basis to have children and contribute to the raising of a family. Approximately one‐third of working women in North Sydney are employed on a part‐time basis. Part‐time or casual workers often have a number of superannuation accounts with small balances that they make little or no effort to trace. The government believes that the retirement savings accounts may offer an attractive solution to this problem. I am very mindful of the time allowed for the debate. So I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Martin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate about the future of the auto industry which is going on in the Australian community and in this House today is very much a debate about regional economies and regional jobs. Yes, it is an issue to states such as South Australia, Victoria, Queensland and New South Wales. But, perhaps more importantly, it is an even more important issue in regions such as Ballarat, Bendigo and Geelong and places such as Taree, Nowra, Albury and Orange, just to name a few. It is for that reason that I suggest to the House that the auto industry and the auto components industry play a significant role in building healthy regional economies and building good jobs—real jobs—in regional Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Last week the shadow ministry visited Ballarat. The shadow minister for industry and regional development, Mr Crean, and I also visited Bendigo. During the course of those visits we had cause to sit down and meet with the local communities—their mayors, their councillors, the editors of local papers, business leaders, community leaders, teachers, young people and union people. Their message was simple. From the point of view of the auto industry, it was about the need for a sense of security and the question of jobs, concern about the important role that the auto component industries play in their local towns, the prosperity they create and the need to ensure that, once and for all, the debate about the future of their industry is settled. Take the town of Ballarat, for example, where there are 1,500 jobs directly related to this industry. Similarly in Bendigo. Empire Rubber has today announced, in association with the announcement by the Labor Party yesterday going to the question of tariffs, further investment.

I also called upon the coalition government to ensure that they adopt a bipartisan stance with respect to the Labor Party's announcements on industry policy and the future of the automotive industry. It effectively means that both political parties—all politicians—stand side by side on the need to ensure that this industry survives into the future. It is for that reason that the Labor Party has brought forward a proposition that tariffs in the automotive industry remain at 15 per cent until 2005.

The problem is unfortunately that, while the auto components industry is so important to both Bendigo and Ballarat, neither of the local coalition Mps—the member for Ballarat (Mr Ronaldson) and the member for Bendigo (Mr Reid)—has yet spoken out on this issue in this parliament. Both members should adopt, I suggest, a bipartisan stance on this issue. They should fight for the retention of a reasonable industry policy, and embrace the Labor Party's position as enunciated by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) yesterday. Mr Ronaldson and Mr Reid, I suggest to the House, should not be meek. Like some of their coalition colleagues from South Australia, they should stand their ground and ensure that local jobs in their local regions are protected. They should tell the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) that they too are opposed to the cut in tariffs, that they too support an auto industry tariff at 15 per cent until at least the year 2005.

I was disappointed to notice that, since the coalition was elected in March last year, neither the member for Bendigo nor the member for Ballarat has spoken out in parliament on this important issue, even though this industry is important for both job creation and the sense of security of the people of Ballarat and Bendigo. Take Ballarat: unemployment has reached 8.3 per cent. Take Bendigo: unemployment is at 10.5 per cent. Take Victoria: 30,000 jobs are directly related to the future of the auto and the auto components industries. I would have thought that the representatives of the federal seats of Ballarat and Bendigo would have thought that the issue was so serious that they would have raised the issue in this parliament since being returned at the election held just on 12 months ago. But it seems that it is not important to either Mr Reid or Mr Ronaldson.

You have got to understand that it extends even beyond Ballarat and Bendigo; it is an issue of the utmost importance to the state of Victoria. It affects places such as Altona, Bentleigh East, Brighton, Clayton, Dandenong, Epping, Fairfield, Oakleigh, Preston, Richmond, Reservoir and Thomastown, to name a few towns in Victoria. In my own electorate of Batman it affects 1,200 jobs. I ask the coalition to seriously consider putting aside petty politics and to face up to the question of securing the future of this industry. If it is good enough for the Leader of the Opposition in Victoria and the Premier to stand together on the future of the industry in Victoria, then it is good enough for the representatives of Ballarat and Bendigo to face up to their electoral responsibilities, and the question of job security which was seriously embraced in the Labor Party's announcement on industry policy in the automotive industry in Victoria. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gash, Joanna, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak with pride and enthusiasm on yet another initiative of the Gilmore electorate and the Shoalhaven community in particular. Like many electorates in rural and regional Australia, Gilmore suffers from high youth unemployment—in excess of 30 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: Since this government took office some 12 months ago, many initiatives have been instigated to assist young people to get work. I would like to introduce members to a new and exciting program being developed in my electorate that I am sure could be considered as the embryo of a major youth program across Australia: a Shoalhaven youth support organisation called Shoalcare—which manages a number of youth services, including the Shoalhaven Youth Refuge, the aunties and uncles program and a non‐funded residential hostel and time‐out house—has developed a program called `bring back the elders', which is sponsored by Rotary International.

The bring back the elders program is just that. It is unashamedly turning the clock back to when the more mature, experienced and motivated members of the tribe led, taught and encouraged their young to develop the skills, attitudes and momentum to contribute to the tribe's wellbeing. We may not live in tribes any more, but we do have many who could be described as modern day elders. They occur in every sphere, stratum and job within society. They may be acknowledged by virtue of their position or their fame or known only to the one person whose life they have positively altered. It is these life winners that the program uses to help our youth climb out of the mind numbing welfare dependency to which we have condemned many of them.

The program is about us, the community, retrieving the responsibility we delegated by our neglect to government, to schools and to the streets. The bring back the elders program is designed to assist our elders contribute in a positive way to the lives of the youth in our society. It is designed to put back hope into the lives of our kids and to put meaning into the lives of the elders who do care. The program is not welfare—it is the opposite. It is about giving youth a hand when they want to do better and are wiling to make every effort to try. It is a process of supporting with understanding, helping with knowledge, educating with experience, leading by example and living with respect.

This process has worked for 200,000 years. It is only recently that we have delegated the responsibility for our youth to people who, although they may be well versed in theory, have yet to develop the essential qualities that are so important in being an elder. The understanding of wider community issues, life's pitfalls and benefits, leadership skills and the respect of others are not subjects learnt from a book or at a university; they are learnt by ordinary people as they live productive and fulfilling lives. It is a fact that in our modern society the experience gained by our older population is lost to the youth of today.

The bring back the elders program is designed to utilise that wasted experience by providing the older people in our community with the opportunity to pass on their knowledge to receptive youth. The program works by attracting older, experienced, caring people who are willing to assist in projects created by and for our youth with enthusiastic encouragement, practical demonstrations, intellectual research and just by being someone to learn from. These projects will be developed with the assistance of service clubs and community groups under the guidance of program managers.

The program works by the provision of training sites, development programs, seminars, access business networks, literacy and numeracy development and conferences. It is led by a panel of elders. The coordination of the program is by Shoalcare, with the support of service clubs and sponsorship by the private sector and the media.

It must be remembered that to gain the assistance of these older people, it is vital that the programs they become involved with are seen to be having a positive outcome for the youth. The elders are not going to put a great deal of effort and time into what they perceive to be a lost cause. Each project and activity which develops under the program must contain strategies to ensure that each participating youth grows and can clearly be seen to have gained something through the program.

To sum up, the essence of the program is for every child in Australia to be given the opportunity to work in an environment that builds self-esteem for themselves and respect for their elders. There is no reason why the government, the private sector and the community should not support programs like the bring back the elders program, which has the potential to significantly reduce unemployment in regional and rural Australia, particularly in the Shoalhaven. I fully support the program and I am confident that such excellent initiatives as this one in Gilmore will always have the support of the government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilton, Greg, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this place for the second time this week to draw the attention of the House to the quality and calibre of people who live in the suburb of Carrum Downs in my electorate of Isaacs. Earlier this week I drew the attention of the House to the plight faced by residents of the GK Tucker Settlement run by the Brotherhood of St Laurence within Carrum Downs and the problems that they face with regard to potential nursing home charges.

SPEECH.PARA: On this occasion I rise again to put to the House the need for a post office in Carrum Downs. Residents of this fast growing area were thrilled when a major shopping complex was opened in November 1994. For the first time it meant that residents of the Downs, as it is affectionately known, could have access to a range of shops that they had never before had access to, including a National Australia Bank and a Rainbow supermarket.

What the centre did need to really crank up business in the area and to attract other potential traders and shop owners to the complex was a post office to serve the 14,000 residents of Carrum Downs, given that the nearest post office is some four kilometres away in Lathams Road in the nearby suburb of Seaford.

Carrum Downs has a large population, which perhaps forms a cross-section of the Australian community, comprising young families, sole parents and many older residents, including some who live at the GK Tucker Settlement. They often have to struggle long distances to get to the aforementioned post office in Lathams Road, Seaford. Many of those people were signatories to a petition, which circulated with my support throughout Carrum Downs when, as the then candidate for Isaacs, I was pushing Australia Post to agree with centre management to the establishment of a post office at the Hall Road shopping centre. I have been in regular contact with shopping centre management since that time, in particular, Ms Christine Grayland, who has had many discussions with Australia Post since she wrote to them in December 1994. They responded in that same month, suggesting that a post office was unlikely.

I am pleased to say that following regular intervention of people like myself and senior members of the Carrum Downs community, it would appear that a monetary offer has now been submitted by Australia Post to centre management. Negotiations will now proceed between the parties for the establishment of a post office. Without seeking to intervene in any way in what are clearly private negotiations between the parties, I certainly urge the parties to come to a reasonable arrangement and financial settlement as quickly as possible, given that Carrum Downs residents have not been afforded the opportunity of access to a post office now since many of them moved to the Carrum Downs area up to 15 and more years ago.

I know that the establishment of a post office will delight shop owners, no more so than newsagent, Mr Trevor Waterfall, who was one of the catalysts for generating the aforementioned petition which was signed by 5,000 local residents. I again implore the parties to reach an expeditious and equitable settlement which will ensure that all residents of this rapid growth area are rightly serviced by a proper Australia Post retail outlet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johnston, Ricky, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this evening to congratulate the federal Minister for Health and Family Services, the honourable member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge), on his seven‐point immunisation initiative, which he announced in this place earlier in the week. It was equally encouraging to hear the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) support the measures and I am delighted by this bipartisan support.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that there is no more important issue than our children's health. As a nation, we are fortunate to have the technology to protect our children against preventable diseases. Indeed, we should be doing everything in our power to use this to its optimum.

Around 98 per cent of Australian parents support immunisation of their children. However, this is not translating into action. Statistics show that Australia has appalling levels of immunisation. It is no less than a national disgrace that the immunisation rate is approximately 53 per cent. The immunise Australia program aims to have 90 per cent of children up to two years of age fully immunised, and after that we envisage near universal coverage for children up to the age of six.

I remember well the day I took my two young sons to be immunised. Those were the days when children could not attend kindergarten nor school without confirmation that they had been immunised. However, anecdotal and actual evidence suggests that over the last eight to 10 years this is no longer the case. It is indeed difficult to believe that in a country like Australia we have children dying from preventable diseases. As a nurse, I found it was rare to come across children with diseases such as diphtheria, polio and rubella. It was thought that these were things of the past. So it seems a sad irony that some years down the track these diseases have come back to haunt us through our own complacency and inaction.

Parents who do not fully immunise their children not only put their own children at risk but also put other children in serious danger of contracting a preventable disease. The four children who died of whooping cough in New South Wales last year caught this disease from some older children who had not been immunised. It is indeed a tragedy that these deaths occurred.

Much has been written in the press over the past few months about Australia's low level of immunisation. Because of its importance, I recently conducted a survey in my electorate of Canning asking people their views on immunisation. The survey was timed to coincide with the beginning of the school year and showed that many parents were concerned that their children were at risk of contracting preventable diseases. Ninety-seven per cent of those parents who answered the survey favoured immunisation for their children, and I am positive that they will welcome the measures announced by the government to boost immunisation levels.

As many commentators have noted this week, the government will be using a range of carrots and sticks to guarantee that the levels are increased. These measures have been fully outlined by the minister for health in his ministerial statement on Tuesday and I do not intend to go into details here today. Suffice it to say that I commend the incentive to restructure the maternity allowance for parents so as to provide a bonus for ensuring that their child's immunisation coverage is complete.

In this week's edition of the Bulletin there was a letter from Mr Peter Doherty from the St Jude Children's Research Hospital in the United States. This letter was obviously written before the minister's announcement. However, I thought it worth while to mention part of what Mr Doherty had to say. He said:

It may be hard to deal with a child crying following a vaccination. It is infinitely more difficult to live with the knowledge that your child has died, or is debilitated in the long term, as a consequence of completely preventable infection. Legislation is clearly needed to ensure all Australian children are immunised.

The honourable member for Chisholm has stated that he has no intention of going down in history as a health minister who sat idle on his hands while Australian children died of vaccine preventable illnesses. I congratulate the minister on having the political mettle and courage to introduce these measures and see them through.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins, Harry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night, before the adjournment of the Main Committee, I commenced my remarks on the Commonwealth Services Delivery Agency Bill 1996 by reiterating my concerns about certain aspects of the service delivery agency. One of those concerns that I indicated last night was location and how many agencies it was proposed there would be. I also expressed my concern about what I believe to be a developing theme within this government that certain measures it is taking are not based on what appears to be a transparent basis of need.

SPEECH.PARA: An article in this morning's Melbourne Herald‐Sun showed that there was an apparent lack of justice in the way in which resources are being allocated, and that is another cause for concern. Under the headline `Apprentice shops in jobs strategy', there is an announcement of a one‐stop apprenticeship shop and the announcement that there have been 18 pilot programs announced nationally. Of those 18, there are four in Victoria.

One of the difficulties I have in making comment at this early stage about this announcement is that whist this article appears to indicate that this is `a new weapon to attack rural unemployment', the four centres in Victoria where these shops are going to be opened are: Ballarat, Bendigo and Wangaratta—and I have no argument about the classification of those three cities as being rural—and the fourth is to be opened in Ringwood. Ringwood is very much part of metropolitan Melbourne.

The reason I have disquiet is that the region the electorate of Scullin is in in Melbourne has the highest unemployment rate of all regions in Victoria and has an unemployment rate that is not declining. It makes me wonder why, on the basis of need, yet again, in another new program, which one assumes the government thinks is worthwhile, the region I represent is missing out. This adds to the schools pathways program that the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Dr Kemp) announced earlier this month and adds to other concerns about the way in which some of the new programs the government is proposing are being put in place.

BREAK.PARA: Another aspect I have concern about is that there has been no discussion about how the agency will ensure quality of service. For over 50 years, for instance, the CES has fulfilled, as I said last night, an essential public function in providing assistance to everyone. But, regrettably, right of assistance will be a thing of the past under the Howard government. With employment services now, people are to be screened as to their capacity to benefit. The documentation that has been released thus far contains only the most rudimentary details of this job seeker classification instrument. The questions that need to be posed are: what weighting will be given to variables? What regional variations will be included? What mechanisms for appeal will there be? What mechanisms—and this is very important for the electorate of Scullin—are there to ensure that people with English language difficulties are properly assessed? At the moment, at best, the answers to these questions are vague and sketchy. In some cases those questions are yet to be answered. Another great concern about the way in which the proposed service delivery agency has been developed so far is the way in which DEETYA and social security staff are being left in the dark about how the agency will really impact. This piece of legislation, in part, goes to certain aspects and also indicates that, after the agency is up and running, a lot of these things will be left in the hands of the board and the CEO. This is a cause for grave concern. The people who work in DSS and DEETYA regional offices are very important players in the way in which the Commonwealth government projects itself in local and regional areas. It is of great concern that they are being asked to make very important decisions about their futures without really getting adequate information.

Another aspect of this agency that I expressed concern about back in September was that the way in which the government is setting up the agency—that is, the types of services it will provide and the nature of the agency—poses the question of whether that will lead to privatisation. I do not make that sort of suggestion lightly. If one looks at governments, especially state governments around Australia—and more particularly the Victorian government—that has been the tendency. Max Moore‐Wilton has made statements to the effect that changes to the Public Service will develop a greater definition of policy aspects of the Public Service as against service delivery, which really does indicate that by separating and making them distinct it sets them up as being able to offload or outsource many of the aspects of the Public Service.

I am told that even in Victoria, where this argument has really revolved around service delivery, there is some suggestion that the Kennett government might go down the path of outsourcing policy development. I find the notion that in public administration a government would even devolve itself of direct responsibility for the development of policy very strange.

Something that has been mentioned by other members on this side of the House during this debate about the agency is their concern that the agency—by the very nature of the way it is being set up—is set at a further arm's length away from proper parliamentary scrutiny. Any stage at which this is done is a grave cause for concern. Those aspects of the way in which the agency is being put in place should be revisited and reviewed.

It has been suggested that there is the potential for the agency, some time down the track, to be put out to tender or put out to competition. In other jurisdictions, especially in local government in Victoria where compulsory competitive tendering has been enforced by the state government, the workers in local government have been given the opportunity to make in‐house bids. In some of the examples of outsourcing and tendering within the Commonwealth Public Service, that same sort of opportunity has not been given to workers.

I was a bit dismayed at the response of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott) to a dorothy dixer about the contract for the outsourcing of the information technology activities of the Department of Veterans' Affairs, where a fair opportunity was not given to those people working within the department to make an in-house bid. They were really denied adequate support to address things that were outlined in the contract requirements—such as the purchasing of equipment—to be able to make a proper bid. Indeed, if the Commonwealth government is going to further develop its attempts to outsource and privatise very important aspects of public administration, in fairness to those who work within the Public Service, and indeed, to ensure that the tendering process is as transparent as it can be, I believe that the workers within those areas to be put to tender should be given a fair and very real opportunity to place a competitive bid.

Yesterday, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs made great claims about the savings that were going to be achieved by this particular contract to ISSC Ballarat, Victoria, and made other extraneous comments that, in some way, critics and the union were against providing regional job opportunities and things like that. That was not the issue. The journal Technology Transactions comments about these perceived savings. It says:
The $65 million contract, therefore, superficially appears to be in line‐ball with present costs, rather than saving $20 million, as is claimed.
The journal was mentioning the information technology expenditure of $21 million within the Department of Veterans' Affairs in 1996. Perhaps even this suggested saving is illusory.

I declare an interest of sorts in the Department of Veterans' Affairs activity, having worked for 13 years for the department. At that time, the people who developed the information technology systems in veterans' affairs were leaders throughout the Public Service. The system not only had responsibility for pension payments and monitoring of entitlements but also catered for hospitals throughout the Commonwealth which the department then administered. This system was able to cater for all those things and was well and truly a leader within the Public Service.

The shadow minister led the debate on this legislation and indicated, along with a number of my colleagues, that the opposition sees merit in the notion of bringing together the services of the CES and the Department of Social Security. Although the opposition sees a potential for efficiencies, we cannot understand the requirement to set up the agency in the manner which is suggested by this legislation.

When this type of quasi‐corporatisation of a new agency does occur, it leads to a great fear in the minds of many about what can happen down the track to that corporatised entity. Throughout my years as a government backbencher, the previous Labor government caused me similar concerns in regard to the corporatisation of a number of entities. So I come before the Main Committee as being consistent and having learnt, rather regrettably on some occasions, that it can be the toe in the door to full privatisation.

At some stage down the track, I hope the ministers responsible can give greater reassurance to those who have taken an interest in the development of the agency, those who will be clients and, most importantly, those people who work for the authorities whose functions the agency will subsume, to give them cause for confidence about what their futures might be. I hope they can also give cause to make people feel comfortable that this is not the first step of many that would see a number of the activities of Commonwealth administration outsourced and privatised—given to bidders whose profit motive would lead to some concern about the efficiency of the delivery of what are very important services to clients targeted by the agencies which the service delivery agency will replace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellis, Annette, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This particular bill, the Commonwealth Services Delivery Agency Bill 1996—and the creation of the agency per se—covers an enormous area of government service responsibility. Many speakers have already touched on the creation of the agency with a variety of concerns. One particular area of huge government responsibility that is now going to be contained within this new agency is a very big concern to me, and that is the delivery of employment services. It is that area of the agency that I would most like to concentrate on today.

SPEECH.PARA: Amongst other things, this bill is about the beginning or, should I say, almost the conclusion of the privatisation of employment services. Employment and unemployment is of particular concern in our community today. It touches almost every family in my electorate in one way or another. We need to consider very carefully and very seriously the implications of changing dramatically the delivery of those employment services to our community and, with the inception of the agency, we are going to have a huge number of questions to consider very carefully.

I happen to represent an electorate in the ACT where we, unfortunately, now see consistent unemployment—particularly youth unemployment—swinging between some 30 and 50 per cent. That has been held at a level over recent months. If we couple the moves in the service provision for employment services with the disappearance of employment training programs—actions that I believe are entrenching the long‐term unemployed into long‐term unemployment—and a lack of assistance for those with additional difficulties in obtaining employment, these things are all going to lead to a pretty hopeless situation for a number of those people.

I understand that the CES, through this agency, is going to be replaced by a PEPE, which is a public employment placement enterprise, and the privately run EPE, which is an employment placement enterprise. In my electorate, I have already seen the rationalisation of the CES case management structure with the relocation of those case managers to an area outside my electorate. That is of concern to me even before the agency comes in. I understand that eventually all of these PEPE services will probably be centralised in the city in Canberra.

Previous speakers on this bill have talked about remote rural areas and more remote urban areas. My responsibility is to look after the people in my area and my electorate and I am concerned that, in the current economic climate in Canberra, we are going to see unemployed people isolated even more from the services that I believe they are going to need.

The four CES case managers in my area were handling up to 500 clients. That is an indication of the level of need that a number of people in the community suffering from unemployment and long‐term unemployment really require. We must understand that those people who need the services of a case manager are folk who have one or other difficulties in finding employment. The success rate of the system of case management was proving rewarding, to say the least, and I really think we need to carefully consider the sorts of difficulties that these people undergo when we decide to consider dramatic changes to employment services.

The previous speaker already mentioned some of these people. They are people who have English as a second language, people who are attempting to re‐enter the work force after a period of being outside it and people with a disability of one form or another, or one degree or another, who really need some additional assistance.

BREAK.PARA: When the agency comes into place and the EPEs or PEPEs are located where they will be, my strong suspicion and my understanding from speaking to people in my electorate is that they will probably all have to travel to the city. In some cases from my electorate that is 30 to 40 kilometres for some of them. I want to know whether they will get extra travel assistance to do that or whether they will have to rely solely on the sort of income they unfortunately have to survive on to get around. I also understand that the PEPE will not be established in Tuggeranong, which is the major town centre area in my electorate. Since the inception of this government, and unfortunately with the assistance of the local ACT government, the employment base in my electorate is really shrinking. The suspicion is that the EPEs will probably not locate there either, for the simple reason that it will not be marketable for them to do so.

Where does this leave the clients who are actively seeking employment opportunities in my area? When they eventually find their way to the PEPE, what will confront them under this new agency proposal? I understand that we have already started to move down the track of having touch screens for people to use when they walk into a CES. I find that pretty inhuman. I have spoken to some people who have gone into the local CES, which still exists in my electorate, walked up to a touch screen, pushed a few buttons, found that there is no work in their area and walked out the door. I do not find that terribly constructive in terms of counselling or assisting these people.

I also understand that, with the surge in technology, Internet connections will be possible. I think that is fantastic. I am not at all against the utilisation of information technology. That is all very well, as long as people have access to the Internet. My major concern is that, first of all, you either have the access and you can use it, or you do not, and you have to go to a centre where it is available. Will the PEPE or EPE have the Internet available and will that be a replacement for human contact? If that is the case, how do we counsel ourselves in dealing with the implications that may have for some of clients I have already described?

Even more importantly, currently you can go to your local CES and seek referrals to available jobs. An example could be a motor mechanic who is current unemployed. Theoretically, he could go into a CES now and, with any luck, receive in that one place referrals to maybe two, three or more jobs. When an EPE is established, under that proposal as I understand it, what will happen is that he will go to EPE number one and he may get a referral for a motor mechanic's position. He can go to EPE number two which will be in a completely different physical location and possibly find another job referral. Then he could possibly go to EPE number three. What I am really getting at here is that, instead of having a very efficient, economical and proficient system of job referral, it will all be heaped upon these people to track around their respective areas, no matter where it is in Australia, and do all they can to try to find a job referral from a number of sources. I have a great deal of difficulty understanding the efficiency of this and would welcome some explanation from someone at some stage, if I am correct in my assumptions as to how that is going to work.

At the moment, I understand that anyone can wander into their local CES and seek some advice of one sort or another. But under the new system I ask the question: is it true that only benefit recipients will receive that service free? I do not know the answer to that question. I am posing it. Is it true that only benefit recipients will now be able to get those services free if they go into a PEPE, and will others have to pay for these services? I do not know.

How may this impact, given the removal of the minimum rate of payment for youth training allowance? What will happen with the new common youth allowance? Potentially how many young people will possibly not be eligible for what I would like to term free employment services? As I said, I do not know the answer to these questions, but they are questions being posed to me by people in my electorate and they deservedly require appropriate answers. The important point is that the questions are legitimate and they are of concern. Given an appropriate answer, those queries could be satisfied. However, I would really emphasise that we need to have some good explanation.

Another question I wanted to ask concerning this agency employment service aspect is: what guarantees will surround the operations of these EPEs, in particular? They are going to be private enterprises. Many of them will emerge from excellent businesses that already exist out there as training and job assistance enterprises. I know some of them and the operators of some of them. They are of exemplary reputation and run very good services. Some of those may, in fact, evolve into becoming an EPE. What will be done to test the bona fides of all people wishing to create an EPE in the future? I would like to pose a couple of important questions in relation to that.

I understand that the PEPEs will be accountable, to some extent, to government, whilst the EPE will be pretty much a free agent, even though the PEPE is having to compete commercially with its counterpart. Does this not seem a bit confusing? It seems a bit contradictory to me. I understand that, when an EPE successfully places a client into employment, after a period of 13 weeks of that successful placement the final payment will be made to the EPE agency in relation to that client. That is fine, but what guarantees will there be that no collusion can occur between an EPE and an employer? I am not suggesting for a moment that everybody in this game will be corrupt. I believe that it is the responsibility of the government to make absolutely certain that we do not close the stable door after the horse has bolted. That is a very legitimate question.

The defence could be that, if we—the government or the authorities—review and monitor and find that something inappropriate has occurred, that particular EPE may not be relicensed. In my view, that is a bit late. I do not know what guarantees there would be to stop people from setting up a business, making a heap of money and not caring if they never get relicensed. I am not predicting that this will happen. Has that been thought about, and what guarantees and conditions are in place to counter it?

Another important question is raised in the case of a client who is in the `hard to place' category, such as the long‐term unemployed and the person with difficulties in finding work—all very legitimate reasons. When people are in that category—and I believe I am right in saying this—a part payment will be made to the EPE, which is a sort of kick‐off payment to begin the process when they take that client on. What guarantees are there that that EPE will remain faithful to that `difficult' client? And, should employment not result, what is going to be accepted as a reasonable period of time and amount of effort for that particular client? Again, this is a very legitimate question. I have not seen anything that answers that query, hence my reason for bringing it up.

I am extremely concerned that these questions are serious questions and legitimate concerns. Hopefully, satisfactory answers can be found. I would welcome it, because that means that the people I fear for need not have that fear, and I would be the first to tell them. They do not deserve to have any additional concern laid on them. After all, they are people who are seriously and sincerely looking for work. They have a whole heap of problems; they do not need this on top of it. I share the concerns of many in the community about the role of the creation of the agency. They are very legitimate queries and it is my responsibility to bring these to the attention of the authorities in creating this new agency.

As I said at the outset, I have deliberately concentrated on the employment services aspects of the agency, given what I think is the very sad state of the employment and economic picture in my electorate. I do not think that I am Robinson Crusoe. Very many people could stand up in this Main Committee or in the other place and make reference to their concerns for members of their constituencies who are currently finding it very difficult to survive in the employment market. We talk a lot—as does the government—about the need to concentrate more on job creation and the employment market. I tend to believe that we are a little bit more sincere and that when we say that we really worry about these people, we really do want to do something to help them. I do not understand how the creation of an agency, with what I consider at this point in time to be a very confusing change in the employment service delivery for our clients in the community, can really be justified at the same time that we are facing disturbing trends in employment and unemployment figures, and disturbing trends in certain areas of economic development around the country. In my electorate in the ACT, the economy is in such a bad state that job prospects are going down, not coming up.

I value this opportunity to speak on this bill and bring to the attention of the Main Committee concerns that I believe are very legitimate and real. I welcome the opportunity to hear honest and truthful responses to the queries that I have raised today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock, Philip, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr RUDDOCK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —If I may, I will first table the corrigendum to the explanatory memorandum to the Commonwealth Services Delivery Agency Bill, which deals with the outlying and financial impact statement, and there is an explanation associated with that. I intend to take up a number of matters that were raised about the bill. I welcome the comments of the member for Namadgi (Ms Ellis), who is the only member remaining—perhaps that is because she has just concluded her statement. I am sure she will remain for the whole of my contribution in order that I might respond. At the end of my speech I am going to use the opportunity to speak on some of her observations. But she may have to inform her many colleagues who had a contribution to make, who I note are not here, of my response. There is a great deal I want to say about their comments as well.

SPEECH.PARA: In the short time available—perhaps the honourable member will want to move an extension—I want to refer to the amendment moved by the honourable member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson) and say that provisions such as clause 14 of the bill are common in other Commonwealth legislation. The general policies of the government are generally applicable to government operations, and by their very nature are therefore public statements and open to scrutiny and public accountability.

The second part, relating to the board's unfettered power to set terms and conditions of the chief executive, is factually incorrect. Clause 31 provides for the terms and conditions applicable to the CEO to be determined by the board. However, under clause 13(1) the minister may give directions to the board and in relation to the terms and conditions of the chief executive officer. Particulars of any directions given by the minister under this section in a financial year must be included in the annual report for that agency for that year.

BREAK.PARA: The third matter deals with the erosion of Public Service terms and conditions through the agency's ability to employ staff under terms and conditions different from those specified in the Public Service Act. As stated in the information kit sent by the minister on 17 February to all members and senators, all staff of the Department of Social Security and the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs will transfer to the agency under the Public Service Act and remain under this act. No staff member who transfers will be placed under any pressure to move outside the Australian Public Service conditions of employment.

The general expectation for the future is that the primary staffing framework for the agency will continue to be under the Public Service Act, and flexibility will be developed to improve customer service, including more personalised service and more extensive opening hours.

I refer to the issues that have been raised in the course of this debate, and there have been many. The honourable member for Batman raised the issue of lack of scrutiny by parliament, and that theme was picked up by some of his colleagues. In my second reading speech, the issue of scrutiny of the agency was raised. The member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris) suggested that the agency is a major step away from the Westminster system. The second reading speech makes it clear that the agency will have full public and parliamentary scrutiny. It will be subject to the Audit Act, financial regulations, finance directions and parliamentary committees.

As the agency is to be established within the Social Security portfolio, it will be accountable to parliament through the Minister for Social Security. The funding of the agency will be determined by the government and reflected in the appropriations through the existing budget process. Annual appropriations will be included in appropriations bills prepared for the budget and will come before parliament for scrutiny and passage and will be subject to the estimates process. These, of course, are matters that are fundamental to the Westminster system. The agency will deliver its services as part of the Commonwealth and not as a separate entity of the Commonwealth. It is not a corporation. It is not corporatisation.

I have already mentioned the terms and conditions for employees. The agency is part of the Commonwealth. As the second reading speech makes clear, it is part of the core of the Commonwealth's operations. Staff who transfer will be under the act and they will stay under the act. They will not be placed under any pressure. I have made these observations before.

The member for Batman referred to a $350,000 remuneration package to the CEO. I am told that the salary package is equivalent to that of the mid‐range departmental secretary, which is approximately half the amount suggested by the member for Batman. The House will be interested to know that this fact was confirmed in the social security legislation committee hearings in response to questions from the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Faulkner. So to make that suggestion flies in the face of any information that has been provided publicly. As the information was provided in an answer to a question by the opposition, one would have thought that the spokesman would have been apprised of them. In fact the opposition knew that the CEO was not being paid anything like that amount.

It is really quite disgraceful that these allegations have been made. When the Labor Party were in office they established a number of agencies, one being the Australian Defence Industries, as a separate entity. I believe that in those circumstances the CEO was paid substantially larger amounts, quite unlike the circumstances pertaining here. In other circumstances, if being provocative, you would use terms to describe behaviour of that sort.

The member for Batman has made comments doubting the credentials of the chairman, Mr Robin Marrett. The member has been selective in providing the background of Mr Marrett. It seems the honourable member for Batman believes that a corporate background makes a person unsuitable for the agency. In the government's view that is not correct. It qualifies him very much for the task. He has previously worked for Mobil Oil. He has a strong involvement and interest in the community, especially in working with young unemployed people. He has worked in the public sector before, for the South Australian government, in a statutory position. He has well rounded, relevant experience which we believe is well suited to the task.

There have been suggestions that we might punish the unemployed, attack those in need, and that there will be a reduction by amalgamating services, particularly in regional and rural areas. We would dispute each of these observations as they are made. We see the arrangements that we are making here as being a basis for delivering more efficient services; that is, the streamlining of services into a one stop shop. It was something that was very often talked about by members on both sides of the House over a long period of time, and this is a firm, determined move to achieve that outcome. The Labor Party had more than 13 years in office to be able to address some of these concerns.

Sometimes young people have to attend a social security office and also a CES office and there are instances where, for locational reasons, those offices are in different suburbs. That was the situation in my own electorate for some time. I had a social security office in west Ryde and a CES office in top Ryde. The public transport service was either on the railway line or on bus routes. Unless you had private transport, it was quite difficult to get from one side of Ryde to the other. A one stop shop for the provision of these services is something that people have put a great deal of emphasis on over a period of time. It reduces the complexity for individuals and for the community. The needs of people for a high quality service really are above the boundaries of Commonwealth departments.

The government has a strong commitment to rural and regional Australia. The agency will have an extensive network of over 300 offices and services. There will not be a halving of services as has been suggested, I think mischievously, by some, particularly the member for Batman. We expect an increase in the number of agency shopfronts. The agency will build on the already available DSS network. It will not be a reduction in service in that sense.

For example, the agency will have offices in Mareeba, Townsville and Cairns and an extensive range of offices in other parts of rural and regional Australia. It will provide specialist services. It will take on all the existing DSS offices, visiting services, teleservice centres, family service centres and retirement service outlets, which will form the core of the agency's service outlets.

The implementation of the agency is taking a particular interest in the operations for improving services to rural and regional Australia. Visiting services will continue to smaller and remote towns. The special rural task force of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman) has been examining the effectiveness of information and services to rural areas. The recommendations of the task force will be taken into account in planning the agency's services.

In relation to unemployment and Working Nation and Labor's record, a number of speakers from the opposition have raised issues relating to employment policies. There is legislation before the parliament in relation to employment assistance and services. The debate on these issues is best dealt with in that context. The agency will, of course, deliver the unemployment services and assistance in the legislation which is passed by the parliament. The agency will have a wide range of specialist services to assist customers with special needs. For example, there will be extensive services for people from non-English speaking backgrounds, including multilingual telephone information, interpreting services, translation services, staff with multilingual and migration skills, and migrant liaison officers.

Labor presided over the highest level of unemployment since the Great Depression of 11.2 per cent. Unemployment for youths was as high as 50 per cent in some areas. They threw one million Australians onto the unemployment scrap heap under what was termed by the former Prime Minister as `the recession we had to have'.

It is in that context that I simply say in relation to the comments by the honourable member for Namadgi that she is a new member. I do not blame her for the policies of the past, but her colleagues were in office for 13 years and had the opportunity to deal with those issues over that time. We have been in office for just under a year. This is a new and important initiative and it is one that ought to be taken at face value. It is designed to provide a better range of services, including, I might say to the honourable member for Namadgi, new employment service arrangements. They do not represent the death knell of the role served by the CES and they certainly do not represent a loss to the nation of the expertise now found in that organisation.

For a start, some 3,000 staff will transfer from DEETYA to the Service Delivery Agency. Around two-thirds of those are CES officers. This is the expertise that the government has at the moment. That staff core will be able to be used in this service and, in our view, in a more efficient and effective way to assist clients. As I have said before, those employed in the agency will be employed under the Public Service Act.

In establishing the Public Employment Placement Enterprise as a wholly owned government company to compete with employment placement enterprises from the private and community sector, PEPE will be competing from a position of very substantial comparative advantage. In particular, it will have the very considerable advantage of over 50 years experience of the CES in this business area. That expertise is precisely in the areas of activity which will occur in this market. It will have staff who know the areas of business activity available in a region and where jobs might be available, it will know the job seekers and it will know the employers and other players who are committed to helping them. Further, those staff will be relieved of many of the constraints and inflexibilities which tie down those in the public sector, so that they can undertake their jobs in a more effective way.

Finally, the government has made it very clear that it will ensure that the PEPE is set up for success. The commitments made by the government to CES staff late last year on key terms and conditions of service were directed at reassuring the staff on these matters and thereby enabling them to focus their skills and energy on ensuring that it is the successful player that we intend and expect it to be. In short, far from throwing away what the CES has brought to the community over the last 50 years, we hope to build on that and provide a more effective contribution.

I will deal with some of the comments in relation to Working Nation. The former government spent something of the order of $2 billion in its last budget in an attempt to manipulate unemployment statistics. It spent $500 million on the new work opportunities program which had a four per cent success rate. You were four per cent more likely to get a job if you did that program than if you had nothing to do with it at all. It was not really a very successful program for the great majority of young unemployed if it only had a four per cent success rate.

The cost per job per participant in the program was $143,000. An enormous amount of money was spent to obtain one person a job. I think the young persons involved would have perhaps preferred to have the $143,000. We have taken the best of Working Nation. We have sought to build on the case management technique and to get rid of some of the other more costly parts of the exercise.

In the few moments available to me, I will deal with—and I will watch the time—the start up costs of the agency. The member for the Batman cannot have it both ways. On the one hand he complains that the government is not providing adequate resources for the agency and then on the other he suggests that we are spending too much. The government is committed to setting up the agency to work effectively and to make sure it improves the services to customers and brings the services of a number of departments to one place. We are therefore prepared to make a substantial start up investment in the agency of $48.8 million, of which $36.1 million will be spent in the first year and $12.7 million in 1997‐98. The savings in 1997‐98 will offset the cost in that year. At the same time, the government expects that the agency will deliver efficiencies and savings to the budget by getting rid of the duplication that exists under the present arrangements.

The honourable member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin) raised some issues in relation to child care. Obviously, the new child‐care arrangements are intended to come into force on 1 January 1998. Consultations are taking place in relation to those proposals with the child‐care industry. The outcomes will be considered by ministers. Legislation to give effect to the child‐care policy will mean that changes will be introduced in due course. That will be the proper time to debate those issues. The agency will administer the legislation, as passed by the parliament, and we will look at the most effective means of delivering child‐care assistance and the child‐care rebate. If this agency is the most appropriate way for that to be done then obviously that will occur.

I will conclude my remarks by commenting on what the honourable member for Barton (Mr McClelland) said. He suggested that the administrative review of the agency's actions would be impossible. I am told that that is clearly incorrect. The growth of administrative review in Australia has been very considerable. I for one would, on many occasions, like to question the appropriateness of administrative review in many of the areas in which it now operates.

In this area, as the explanatory memorandum to the bill makes clear, the existing administrative review mechanisms—that is, internal review by authorised review officers and review by the Social Security Appeals Tribunal and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal—will continue to operate. The member for Barton also suggested that the chairman, the CEO, would have absolute discretion as to how they carry out their functions. That is clearly incorrect.

As I have already noted, decisions of the CEO and officers of the agency, who will be taking decisions that will affect customers, will be open to the existing administrative review mechanisms. Further, the provisions that the member for Barton referred to, which confer power on the individuals concerned, are unexceptional when compared to the provisions of other legislation relating to statutory authorities. They merely ensure that the persons in question have the necessary powers to carry out the functions that are conferred upon them.

The member for Barton also suggested that, under the provisions contained in the bill, powers of delegation would be unfettered and could be exercised by an 18 year old on the counter. Leaving aside the slight on 18 year olds—perhaps I should draw that to the attention of 18 year olds in the honourable member's electorate—this merely reflects what is currently happening in government departments.

Under the Social Security Act, for example, powers are delegated. They are delegated as necessary and only to appropriate levels within the current department. The delegation arrangements will be of the same character under the agency. I think that ought to be understood. I do not think that the comments that have been made by honourable members in any way detract from the measures that are before us. They are worthy of support. I encourage this House to give the bill prompt passage.
