TALK.START.PARA: —As it is necessary to resolve this question to enable further questions to be considered in relation to this bill, in accordance with standing order 277, the bill will be returned to the House for further consideration.

DEBATE.TITLE: VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (1996‐97 BUDGET AND OTHER MEASURES) BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 26 February, on motion by Mr Bruce Scott:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradford, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have the opportunity to speak in this House on veterans affairs. I normally take the opportunity to do so in recognition of the important role that veterans play in the life of our community. The amendments that the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (1996‐97 Budget Measures) Bill introduces make minor changes to some of the measures in the veterans legislation. It effects change to mirror amendments made to a similar social security measure and introduces the further veterans affairs budget commitments.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to reiterate this government's commitment to veterans, which is further demonstrated by this legislation we are dealing with. The government believes that veterans are important. In fact, when looking back at some of the documents we produced prior to the election which give an indication of this, I reflected on these words:

The Coalition remembers and applauds the contribution of all war veterans for the freedom we enjoy today and recognises the special standing of the veteran community and their right to the highest levels of support and respect from today's community.

Within the bounds of our economic capacity the Coalition will always attempt to err on the side of generosity in the levels of support it provides our Veteran community. This will be based on the fundamental principle that Government care and support ought to be extended to veterans and their dependants as compensation, not welfare.

When we have debated these sorts of issues in this parliament over the years that I have been here, I have always been at great pains to remind people that when we talk about veterans benefits we are not talking about welfare; we are talking about compensation. I believe that all of our decision making in respect of veterans affairs needs to be based firmly on an understanding and an acceptance of that principle.

I was reminded by one of my colleagues a short time ago that it is only a couple of months before we commemorate Anzac Day again. I am sure that all members in this place look forward to Anzac Day as a very special opportunity to mix with the returned service personnel in our electorates. It is a day we enjoy and a day tinged with sadness as we remember those who paid the ultimate sacrifice. Once again, that day is coming around. For the older veterans it probably comes around all too quickly once a year.

The coalition government has a very substantial array of matters within its veterans affairs policy. Some of them are enacted in this legislation that we are dealing with. Importantly, our commitment is underlined by our belief that all existing veterans entitlements should be maintained. We believe that there are some anomalies within the area of veterans benefits which have been of longstanding concern to the veterans community, and we are addressing a number of those.

One issue that needs attention is the continuation of the war widow pension to war widows who have been involved in a veteran remarriage. I raise this issue because I understand the government has undertaken to review a number of issues and this is one that seems to come up from time to time. A constituent raised it with me recently.

Whilst I do not want to reflect in any way on a veteran's right to remarry, it does cause concern, particularly when we realise that many war widows have received that status—that is what it is—by virtue of the long service that they have given to a veteran. The fact that my mother happens to be a war widow probably colours my view of this to some extent. She cared for my father for some 40 years after the war before he eventually died of war of a war caused illness.

I did not want to take up a lot of time on particular matters, because they are not in any way contentious, but I did want to pick up on a couple of issues that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott) raised in his second reading speech, and that he has been involved with in recent times. I commend him for his commitment to the Australian services nurses national memorial and I am pleased that the government has committed $100,000 towards that project. The minister paid tribute to nurses in his speech at the unveiling of that memorial on Saturday, 15 February, and in the dedication of that site on Anzac Parade which, of course, is a very fitting place for it.

The other issue relates to the Korea war memorial, which is an ongoing matter of concern to the veteran's community, to which this government is committed. The government has committed $200,000 towards that project, and I am very pleased that it has. There is some concern within the Korean veteran's community that the project is not moving ahead as quickly as they would like it to. I have explained to them that the government has been very generous in its commitment and that, as with other memorials—like the nurses memorial and the Vietnam memorial—they need to be active in raising funds to bring that project to fruition. Nevertheless, I am pleased that the government has made that commitment to the Korea war memorial and I do hope that they will be able to meet the time commitments for its completion.

I would like to mention briefly the government's commitment to younger veterans, predominantly Vietnam veterans—although most of those are not quite so young these days, but I am sure they are quite happy to be described as younger veterans. Younger veterans also include veterans from some of the peacekeeping forces who have also achieved the status—I use the word `status' again because I think it is the right word to use—of having returned from active service. I am pleased that the government is committed to looking at the particular problems of younger veterans, Vietnam veterans in particular.

I was very pleased that the minister recently announced his commitment to further research and investigate the effects on Vietnam veterans of chemical exposure to what is broadly termed Agent Orange; I am not sure that that is the actual chemical description of it. The minister has been committed to the Vietnam veterans' community in grappling with that issue and determining whether there is genuine cause for concern. I know that the veterans maintain that there is cause for concern; I believe that we need to carefully investigate that.

In the context of this legislation, I place on the record that I recently had the privilege of visiting Washington. Probably a large number of Vietnam veterans have visited the Vietnam veterans' wall of remembrance in Washington. It is the sort of thing that all Australians who are going to Washington should place on their itineraries.

TALK.START.PARA: —A moving experience.

—As the member for Groom said, it is a moving experience. It is a poignant reminder to Americans and others that over 50,000 Americans gave their lives in Vietnam. Each one of those 50,000 names is inscribed on the marble wall. As we said, it is a moving experience to walk along that wall and see the impact of the sacrifices that so many Americans made in that war and to recognise that over 500 Australians also died in Vietnam. Whilst that might be a small number compared with the more than 50,000 Americans who died, in terms of Australia's commitments to wars, it is nevertheless a very substantial commitment. The Korea memorial, which is almost adjacent to the Vietnam memorial, is also well worth visiting. Australia made a significant contribution to the Korean war.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to pre-empt this to any great extent, but the minister is shortly to announce—it may have been this week—a program of commemorative activities to take place over the next four years. We all believed that Australia Remembers was an excellent year, and we paid due credit to the former minister, Con Sciacca, for the personal contribution he made. Perhaps ironically, the fact that he was running around Australia putting so much effort into that event meant that he did not attend to matters in his own electorate as diligently as he ought to have and, of course, he was not re-elected. We all pay him due credit for the effort he put in.

I am looking forward to seeing what the government is planning for this forthcoming four‐year program of commemorative activities. As the minister in his second reading speech on this legislation said:

This program will publicly and proudly honour the debt owed by all Australians to our veteran community through a range of programs of commemoration and education, and through the restoration of important memorials.
That is worthy of our support.

As I said at the outset, the legislation before us is fairly straightforward and I imagine it is totally non‐controversial. I am sure it will be supported by the parliament. It delivers on some of our promises to veterans, and I am pleased to be part of a government which is committed to veterans. My two colleagues, both of whom have a particular interest in veterans affairs, and I will ensure that the government continues to not only honour its commitments to veterans but also resolve wherever possible some of the ongoing concerns that veterans have. There will always be concerns.

When I was in America I had a meeting with the American department of veterans' affairs. They also cannot keep everybody happy as there are obviously issues at the margin which are difficult to resolve. In fact, not only are they contending with a number of concerns of Vietnam veterans but also they are now having to deal with this Gulf War syndrome, which has created a huge problem for them and a new lot of veterans who are suffering illnesses for which they have to be cared. It was interesting to have that discussion with the American department and to find that on a day to day basis they also do some of the things that our department does here. I try to give credit where it is due—it is not always due—so, in the presence of the department officials, I say that I really think veterans are very well served by our Department of Veterans' Affairs on the ground, at the coalface—not here in Canberra, I suspect, where the engine room is. I very rarely hear any criticism of the department, not so for the politicians or policies. I know you would agree, Madam Deputy Speaker, that with our facilities on the Gold Coast and Southport in particular our veterans are very well served by the staff of the Department of Veterans' Affairs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin, Bob, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address certain aspects of the veterans affairs amendment bill, which seeks to build upon and ensure the government's commitment to our nation's veterans is continually enhanced. In detail, this amendment bill seeks to undertake measures pertaining to the transfer of carer service pensioners and carer income supplement recipients to the Department of Social Security and for the Department of Veterans' Affairs to pay and administer on behalf of the Department of Social Security the age pension of certain disability pensioners and their partners.

SPEECH.PARA: In little over a century, Australians have been under arms and engaged in war on some nine different occasions, not to mention several further peacekeeping missions abroad. These of course were engagements which I humbly say were begun by politicians but were fought and ultimately won by soldiers. It may be argued the conflict in Vietnam was a `police action' only, but to those who served and for those who lost loved ones, let me assure the House, it was without doubt a war—a battle which unmentionable pages in history have tackled and have told, story upon story, the passion it instilled in people both on the main front and on the home front. One of our great generals, Sir John Monash, of Anzac fame is quoted as saying:

The nation that wishes to defend its land and its honour must spare no effort, refuse no sacrifice, and make itself so formidable no enemy will dare assail it. A League of Nations may be an instrument for the preservation of peace, but an efficient army is a far more potent one.

The still strongly accepted ideal of having a standing army in this country has been counterbalanced by the reality that it is the homecoming, the aftermath of war, that has brought tremendous social cataclysm affecting every part of national life.

It is often incomprehensible for the Australians who did not go to war to know what happens on the battlefield. Soldiers who were `ardent innocents' leaving for war would return to an albeit continued stable world but where values had changed. Their homecoming, while not physically crippling, is, however, emotionally exhausting. As the Englishman and World War I veteran Tommy Atkins put it so eloquently, most returning soldiers know that `all one gains from war are taxes, widows, wooden legs and debt, and returning warriors should rust in peace or rot in hospital'.

One can come away with an enormous bulk of material written about war that shines little, with little respect on leaders, on politicians and on the military manipulators of young men. However, I am heartened to know that this government, just like the previous one, continues to remain committed to ensuring that our veterans receive the recognition they so justly deserve—in the form of not just monuments, medals or certificates but the real lasting provisions of quality living and treatment, be it in the provision and administration of pensions or the carers who look after our veterans.

BREAK.PARA: It would be remiss of me if I did not mention the former Minister for Veterans' Affairs, the Hon. Con Sciacca, for his very worthwhile contribution to the Australia Remembers program and on his personal interest in the welfare of our veterans. The current Minister for Veterans' Affairs, the Hon. Bruce Scott, follows the tradition of the importance of ensuring the contributions government makes to the veterans community is more than just sustained.

Australia, through its Department of Veterans' Affairs, has recognised the debt of gratitude to our veterans community. Currently, the department is responsible for the care of over 300,000 veterans and their dependants. The coalition government has guaranteed to maintain all existing veterans entitlements. The bill corrects in most parts the anomalies in these entitlements. In addition, this bill improves the administration of these veterans programs and service delivery.

In the electorate of Paterson I represent many returned soldiers—many now retired and living in the water wonderland that is Port Stephens and particularly within Nelson Bay itself. Indeed, many more are etching out an existence on the land, in regional agriculture, in timber and increasingly the eco‐tourism centres of Gloucester, Bulahdelah and Dungog, to mention but a few.

Notably, some 3,000 service personnel are now posted to the RAAF base at Williamtown—a work force the same size as BHP at Newcastle, members may be surprised to know, and growing not only in number but, critically, in its importance to the region itself. Williamtown and indeed the Hunter is at the potential hub of being the aeronautical and avionics centre of excellence and production in Australia. It is a vision I have been keen to see enacted for some time now, and I will continue to do what I can to help chart its new course from a pipedream to reality and provide a new exciting economic spur to our region. It is also a vision, I am happy to say, the New South Wales state government is seemingly also becoming very chirpy about, which can only be of benefit to the Hunter.

Like many of my colleagues, I also proudly represent the local Vietnam veterans organisation, headed by President Brian Chandler and Secretary Barry Myer, within my local community. It is these people who are currently perhaps in greatest need of and will benefit most from the amendments in this bill. I therefore fully support the commemoration, health care, housing, rehabilitation and compensation measures the government is advocating with the general overriding support provided by the opposition.

When you look at the amendments from closer range, the sensibility and practicality of this bill bears plenty of fruit. For instance, there is recognition of our Victoria Cross winners, currently numbering but three—Sir Roden Cutler, Mr Ted Kenna and our most recent one, from the Vietnam conflict, Mr Keith Payne—who will benefit from the change to pay an allowance of $2,500 per year instead of $250. That is the kind of recognition that I think you will agree, Madam Deputy Speaker, is both valid and very warranted.

Further, the inclusion of the Commonwealth bearing the transportation costs when a cash strapped veteran dies away from his or her home whilst obtaining treatment will be of great benefit and will provide peace of mind to veterans generally and also to the families of veterans for those few facing that predicament. I know it will be an initiative particularly well received by veterans in rural and regional Australian communities.

The amendment to correct the anomalies in the defence service home scheme thus extends those rights to personnel who have served in areas not previously covered, those areas being Cambodia, Somalia and Yugoslavia. I bring to the attention of the current minister, the Hon. Bruce Scott, that there seems to be one group left out; that is, those who served in the Gulf War. That is an issue that does need to be addressed. Those from my electorate who went there should have no doubt that I will be taking up that issue with the minister in due course. In addition to the extension of rights outlined above, restrictions have been removed on a widower of an eligible World War II servicewoman to obtain another initial loan on the basis of his widower status. This bill is about equity for all.

I now wish to address in detail my support for the transfer of payments made to recipients of the carer service pension and carer income support to the Department of Social Security, where they will receive a carer payment. The amendments in this part of schedule 1 of the bill remove all carer provisions from the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986, allowing the recipients to transfer to similar payments under the Social Security Act 1991. The three streams of income support for carers in the Veterans' Entitlements Act are: carer service pension where caring for a service pensioner veteran; carer service pension where caring for a non-pensioner veteran; and, carer stream of income support supplement. These carer payments are similar to carer payments made under the Social Security Act. At present the Department of Veterans' Affairs pays carer service pensions to fewer than 100 carers. In comparison, the Department of Social Security pays carer pensions to approximately 24,500 carers.

Having only one department responsible for carer pensions will simplify the delivery of assistance to carers and promote administrative efficiency. The pension of those who might be adversely affected by this transfer to a similar payment under the Social Security Act 1991 is preserved in schedule 5 of this bill.

This measure will be well received by the many veterans in my electorate of Paterson and, in particular, those who are residing at and receiving the carer pension in the Harbourside Haven Nursing Home at Shoal Bay—an outstanding facility administered by such genuine, committed, caring people as the Chairman, Bill King; Vice Chairman, Norm McLeod, Secretary, Don Folley; Treasurer, Arthur Wade, Councillor, Geoff Robinson; Manager, Gerry Monohan; and the staff from this excellent aged care facility, provided by Nelson Bay RSL and Citizens Retirement Village Ltd.

Ex‐servicemen, such as the late Eric Buschell of East Maitland RSL and John Whiting, former secretary, are sadly missed by their community. This measure will also be well received by people such as Peter Lord, Secretary of the Maitland RSL; President Ernie Bulmer—a real personality; Ron Kennedy, President of Dungog RSL; and Peter Grigg, President of the Lemon Tree Passage RSL. The list goes on of outstanding contributors to the welfare of the returned service people and their families—people who give advice on almost a daily basis, supporting their communities. Having to deal with just one department will simplify this process enormously.

The other amendment relates to the payment of certain pensioners to allow the Department of Veterans' Affairs to pay pensions to certain disability pensioners. These amendments allow the Department of Veterans' Affairs, acting as agents of the Department of Social Security, to pay and administer the age pension, and in certain circumstances the spouse pension, of certain disability pensioners and their partners. Currently, some 38,000 veterans and their eligible partners are required to deal with both the Department of Veterans' Affairs and the Department of Social Security. In addition to a Social Security age pension, they may also be in receipt of compensation in the form of a disability pension, mainly because of the incapacity arising from war caused injury or disease.

These veterans are not receiving service pensions as they have not rendered qualifying service as defined under the Veterans' Entitlements Act. The proposed agency agreements will be valuable to those dual pensioners who indicate that they would prefer to have their age pensions paid by the Department of Veterans' Affairs. In addition it will allow the payments to be made on the same pay day. Currently, the disability pension is paid fortnightly in one week and the age pension and spouse pension in the other week. To avoid windfall gains from the transfer, the first and any last payment would be a half instalment.

The veteran community will welcome this change. Many representations have been made to my office and to the minister asking the government to allow the Department of Veterans' Affairs to pay all forms of income support to members of the veteran community.

In essence, therefore, I recommend the amendment for the following reasons. The Department of Veterans' Affairs will be allowed to act as an agent for the Department of Social Security to pay and administer the age pension and sometimes the spouse pension of certain disability pensioners and their partners. The Department of Social Security rules will still apply—in other words, the DSS will still count the disability pension as income when assessing these payments. Certain age pensions and spouse pensions will be paid on the usual Veterans' Affairs pay day. Veterans will have the option to allow the DVA to act as an agent to avoid dealing with two departments.

I believe that we do owe the veteran community a debt that is impossible to repay—in other words, what price a life? As a nation, we have on many occasions demanded our young to bear arms to fight conflicts far away from our shores. We have sent them as ambassadors because of our belief that everyone is entitled to live a life free from violence and oppression with the rights of freedom of speech and religion, as we enjoy them in Australia. Often these young people come home maimed in body and in spirit. Often these injuries do not count until the veterans have aged and are not in a position to look after themselves any more. It is then that we have a huge responsibility to come to their assistance—indeed, as they came to ours when we, as a nation, called on them.

Anzac Day and many other commemorative services, such as those for the Battle of the Coral Sea, Long Tan and poppy day—to mention but a few—demonstrate our continued interest in veterans. These services, however, do not necessarily reflect our real responsibilities to veterans. As legislators, we have a real, ongoing responsibility to ensure that our veterans will always receive the best of care and treatment.

In conclusion, I seek to remind this house—and, indeed, all Australians—that in just under two months we celebrate a public holiday, that day being Anzac Day, on Friday, 25 April. Madam Deputy Speaker, through you, I ask that all Australians take time to remember, not just those who have passed, but those who live on in personal torture. We should not just treat Anzac Day as another day off, another long weekend, but as a day where we do pay true respect to those who have passed on and those who still survive.

When those flags are flying at half mast, and we are visiting the war memorials or attending the marches, when we are standing there watching, remembering, respecting those who have fallen and those who have returned, and we see their eyes well up or, perhaps, shed a discreet tear, and if the children should ask you why they are crying, make sure that you tell them that these tears are tears of freedom, tears of pride in nation, mateship and remembrance. They must come to understand that for some it was harder to have lived than to have died. It can be hard—very hard—to carry the memories. We should never, never forget their personal sacrifices for us, the free. Lest we forget.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Tony, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I was certainly greatly moved by the speech of the honourable member for Paterson (Mr Bob Baldwin). If ever a speech had a heart and soul in it, that one did.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the great privileges of being a federal member of parliament is in mixing with the veterans' community; it is something that I will always carry with me. Even though I have been in this job just under one year, I feel that it has been an enormous privilege to mix with that community, to go to various functions, to understand the problems that they continue to face, and to also see their vision—not just for their members and their own families, but also for the community, because they are a very community‐minded group of people. That is why this Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (1996‐97 Budget and Other Measures) Bill is very important in recognising that not only are there problems that have to be addressed in the legislation and improvements that have to be made but also that this group of people will not be forgotten by the community. We will be constantly examining the situation for betterment and improvement in their lifestyle and their day‐to‐day requirements, particularly those who continue to bear the wounds and scars of conflicts in which they have been involved.

It is the community aspect that I want to cover in addressing the bill in its various aspects. Recently I had the privilege of opening the Inverpine hostel and nursing home, which is situated in Ogg Road, Murrumba Downs, in my electorate of Dickson. What really struck me was the fact that there was so much infrastructure in the veterans' community—that is, the infrastructure and support of the ladies' committees, and all those things that are there to raise money and supplement the Commonwealth grants that were made to that particular program. It all came together: it was not merely a case of people demanding a hand‐out and preying upon the government to help them yet again; rather it was an integrated and working relationship between the Department of Veterans' Affairs and the Department of Health and Family Services to produce a facility for the veteran community and the wider community which would benefit not only my electorate but the wider area as well.

In my view, that sort of overall community involvement is a model for other community groups. It is very fashionable to see a number of community groups springing up, but I have not seen that same commitment to community fund‐raising and cooperation with the government in order to produce the product as I have seen in the veteran community. I therefore preface my remarks today by saying that the RSL and the veteran community have got together to be a model for so many other community groups.

The bill itself is the second part of the budget package which honours key pre‐election promises to the veteran community. It contains a number of amendments to the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986. The general thrust of the amendments is administrative reform which reflects the dual aims of achieving greater efficiency in the delivery of services and directing resources into the greatest areas of need.

The bill removes all carer provisions from the Veterans' Entitlements Act, allowing recipients to transfer to a similar payment under the Social Security Act 1991. The carer payments made under the provisions of the VEA are similar to the carer payments made by the DSS, so it certainly makes good sense to transfer the administration of these payments from the Department of Veterans' Affairs to the Department of Social Security. However, it is worth noting that the bill contains a saving provision which preserves the pension of those who might be adversely affected by such a transfer.

The bill amends the Social Security Act to allow the Department of Veterans' Affairs, acting as agent of the Department of Social Security, to pay and administer the age pension and, in certain circumstances, the spouse pension of certain disability pensioners and their partners.

Again, this is an amendment about streamlining administrative procedures. It gives age pensioners who also receive a disability pension an option to choose to be paid both pensions by the Department of Veterans' Affairs.

In future veterans and their partners will have to deal with only one department. Again, this re‐emphasises the government's commitment to move to the `one‐stop shop' style of service provision which has been the hallmark of the administration of this portfolio by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott).

I recall last year that, when war widows were given the opportunity to receive their DSS benefits and DVA benefits from the DVA, most took advantage of the simplified regime. In the long run there will be savings in departmental resources but, more importantly, our veteran community will be better served by these administrative changes.

There are also amendments relating to rent assistance, which recognise the somewhat anomalous situation that can arise where single people choose to share accommodation. Obviously this is an economy but in the end, where these sorts of economies are made, the veteran community at large will be better off.

The bill also makes a number of amendments that will mean that people who currently receive fringe benefits, but not service pensions, will no longer be entitled to receive those fringe benefits after 30 June, 1997. The segment of the veteran community to whom these amendments are directed consists of those whose income has been in excess of pension limits for the past four years.

The government is acting to redistribute available resources to areas of greatest need. There is great sense in these proposals because the government obviously is trying to ensure that the resources that are being spent are going to the areas of greatest need where the greatest benefit will result.

The government has demonstrated by these measures a strong commitment to serving the needs of our veteran community and honouring their contribution and sacrifice. I think the proposals deserve the support of the house. It has been said all along that we must never forget the continuing sacrifices of the families of veterans who have passed on. When we examine these areas we must remember always that Australia owes a debt of gratitude that was referred to by the honourable member for Paterson, who preceded me.

I think the great thing about the attitude of people in the veteran community is that they have a vision, they look ahead, they look to how best they can improve the circumstances of the members they serve and the infrastructure that exists and how they can bring the situation of veterans to the attention of the wider community and set a model for fundraising. In all those areas the veteran community is to be commended and, in particular, I am reminded of the veteran community in my own electorate who have done enormous work in their own and the wider community. I commend these measures to the house.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grace, Elizabeth, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I would also like to endorse the comments of the member for Paterson (Mr Bob Baldwin) in his support for veterans. From the outset we, as a government, need to be vigilant that these veterans are looked after and cared for. This country has a very proud record when it comes to war service. Soldiers on all sides know how brutal war is: it is wasteful and horrifying and the hidden cost to a nation is absolutely extraordinary. Because we, as a nation, are aware of this, Australia has a proud record of care for its veterans—the men and women who made it possible for me to be able to stand here today and participate in governing this country, the men and women who made it possible for Australians to have freedom of speech, freedom of worship and democratic elections.

SPEECH.PARA: The veterans we care for today served in many parts of the world—Europe, Asia and Africa. In my own electorate of Lilley I have four World War I veterans—Carl Howard, aged 95, Edward Smout, aged 99, Horace Bishop, aged 100, and Alfred Mansfield, aged 100. They are all active men and still enjoy a beer and a yarn. They kept all of us totally entertained last Anzac Day. A lot of the stories I could not repeat, but they were very entertaining. It was wonderful to see these gentlemen participate in the breakfast after the service at the War Memorial.

On Anzac Day this year they will be there again with the rest of the locals to remember their friends who were killed during the conflict and those who have passed on since. Each will lay a wreath at the local memorial and will stand with pride for the national anthem and the last post. These are proud men who, along with the veterans from other campaigns, epitomise the loyalty and strength of Australian mateship that was forged on the battlefields around the world. The coalition is firmly committed to their well being and care.

This bill will help veterans even more by allowing the recipients of carers payments to transfer to the Department of Social Security. This will simplify the delivery of assistance to carers and help promote administrative efficiencies. Another change will simplify payments to and communication with veterans. Currently, veterans and their eligible partners are required to deal with both the Department of Veterans' Affairs, in relation to their disabilities, and the Department of Social Security, in relation to their age pension. Now pensioners can choose to have their age pension paid by the Department of Veterans' Affairs and thus avoid dealing with two departments.

The popular support for a concept like this was demonstrated when most of the war widows, who also receive a social security pension, opted to receive all their payments from the Department of Veterans' Affairs. The government has delivered on their support and the change will build on the one‐stop shop approach to service provision.

Another change relates to the better targeting of income support benefits. This bill sets out a new maximum rate of rent assistance for single people who share accommodation. It is reasoned that people in shared accommodation bear reduced rental costs compared to those borne by single people living by themselves. The Department of Veterans' Affairs is implementing this policy initiative for equity reasons.

The government acknowledges Australia's debt of gratitude to our veteran community and their invaluable and selfless contribution to our society and recognises the importance of developing the community's knowledge and understanding of the veterans' war experiences. The government has committed significant funding over the next four years for commemorative activities. These activities will proudly honour our veteran community through a range of programs of commemoration and education and through restoration of important memorials, including the Australian War Memorial.

BREAK.PARA: On Saturday 15 February 1997, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Bruce Scott, was at the dedication of a site on Anzac Parade for the Australian services nurses national memorial. He described it as one of the most satisfying events he had taken part in since becoming minister. The dedication of this site is only the beginning. The task now is to raise the funds so that the memorial can be unveiled as planned in October 1999—the year which marks the century of Australian military nursing services. The government has pledged $100,000 to start the fundraising. It is memorials such as this one planned for Anzac Parade and throughout Australia that become the focus on Anzac Day and help communities remain aware of the service veterans have contributed to this nation.

These initiatives demonstrate the 1996-97 budget's strong and unequivocal commitment to veterans and their families. As the minister said in his second reading speech, benefits and services will continue to be reviewed to maintain their quality, fairness and appropriateness. The government is also committed to improving efficiency in the delivery of these benefits and services. The outcome will be a system that is responsive to the changing needs of veterans and their families and one that directs resources to the greatest need. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott, Bruce, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—Firstly, I congratulate those members who have participated in this debate on the veterans' affairs legislation. I think it demonstrates the genuine interest of both sides of the parliament in the welfare of our veteran community and ensures that we do get it right as a government. I think there has generally been bipartisan support when it comes to issues relating to our veterans and war widows. I also thank the shadow minister for his cooperation as we have worked through this bill. There is perhaps going to be an amendment moved, but I have spoken to the shadow minister and he is generally supportive of the thrust of the bill, as expressed in his speech yesterday in the main chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: In my second reading speech, I outlined the measures in this bill. These focused on the rationalisation of administration of certain pensions between my department and the Department of Social Security. One of the other measures provided for changes to the rent assistance payable to single pensioners who share rental accommodation.

I take this opportunity to foreshadow that the government intends moving a number of amendments to this bill. These amendments will add two other budget measures and will limit the application of a measure in the bill. This will mirror the policy that will be applied to social security payees. Other amendments will make a number of minor and technical changes to the bill.

The bill as presented provides for a lower rate of rent assistance to be paid to single pensioners who share accommodation. This measure is intended to address a current anomaly where two single people who share accommodation can receive $80 a fortnight more in rent assistance than a pensioner couple. The rate of rent assistance for a single pensioner is higher per capita than for a couple. This recognises that, since they live alone, they have to bear the full cost of their accommodation.

When people enter into an arrangement to share accommodation, it is inequitable that they should continue to be paid an amount of rent assistance that was designed to assist those who do not, or cannot, defray their living expenses in this way. The combined rate of rent assistance for single pensioners sharing accommodation will continue to be higher than the amount per capita paid to a couple. This acknowledges the fact that the accommodation needs of most singles sharing will be different to those of a couple.

Social security legislation to effect a similar provision will commence later this year. Before the enabling legislation was passed by this parliament, the legislation was amended to prevent it from applying to disability support pensioners and carer pensioners. This bill provides for the transfer to social security of carer pensions paid under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 from the day these new rent assistance rates are to apply.

One of the amendments I will move later in this debate will preclude the changes in rent assistance from applying to service pensioners or to those who receive an income support supplement because of their permanent incapacity to work. Those who receive income support, because of their incapacity, and their carers are excluded because a unique situation often exists where the shared accommodation arrangement has been entered into to assist the disabled person to continue to live in the community.

I would now like to talk about two budget measures that are to be added to this bill. One of the amendments I will move is to establish a vocational rehabilitation scheme for veterans. This government undertook to closely monitor the long-term care needs of Vietnam veterans. The scheme that is to be introduced into the Veterans' Entitlements Act will provide for early intervention for younger veterans leaving the forces and support for Vietnam veterans. This scheme addresses concerns that have been expressed that some veterans who leave the defence forces have difficulty in making the transition to, and remaining in, civilian employment. It also addresses the concerns that some incapacitated veterans have about participating in a rehabilitation program unless a safety net to protect their pension entitlements is guaranteed by legislation.

The aim of the scheme is to assist veterans to find employment and to continue in employment. The development of the legislation for the scheme has been subject to extensive consultation with the ex‐service community. The proposed legislation was made available to key ex‐service representatives, and the amendments I will move reflect the outcome of that consultative process. This consultation and ex‐service community support is critical to the success of the scheme, details of which are being developed. I want to thank the veterans community for their assistance in developing this scheme. I particularly mention them because they have been extremely cooperative in ensuring that we are able to put this together, and their continued cooperation will be vital to the success of the scheme.

Consultation on the detailed content of the scheme will begin soon so it can be tabled before 1 July 1997. The legislation provides the authority for the scheme and enshrines key income protection for certain veterans who take up employment as a result of a rehabilitation program. The legislation also requires consultation with the ex‐service community before the scheme is finalised and before any changes of significance are made.

The scheme will be available to all eligible veterans, but special provision has been made for those veterans who are receiving a disability pension or a service pension on the grounds that they are prevented by their incapacity from working full time. The legislation being brought forward will guarantee that these veterans will not have their pension reduced—I repeat that they will not have their pensions reduced—while participating in a rehabilitation program under the scheme.

When a veteran begins work as a result of the program, general rate disability pensioners will continue to receive their usual rate of pension. Veterans on above general rate pensions, such as those on the T&PI pension, will retain part of their higher disability pension. This removes the disincentive for pensioner veterans to participate in the scheme.

If the veteran is a service pensioner, only part of the veteran's earnings from employment will be taken into account in calculating the rate of service pension. If at any time the veteran ceases employment, he or she will revert to the rate of disability pension payable when the rehabilitation program was initially undertaken. The amount of service pension will be determined using the usual income and assets test.

As a safeguard, the scheme contains a provision that ensures that veterans will receive at least the same income, from earnings and disability pensions combined, as he or she would have received as a disability pensioner had the veteran not participated in the rehabilitation program and entered employment. These safeguards and guarantees are essential if veterans are to feel the confidence that they can only gain by volunteering for rehabilitation back into the work force, from which incapacity has previously prevented their participation.

The benefits veterans may obtain from participating in a rehabilitation program go beyond the financial advantages. These programs increase a person's self‐reliance and ability to cope with life's tasks, provide opportunities for socialisation and can help improve the quality of the participant's life.

The second budget measure to be added to this bill mirrors changes Social Security is adopting to the treatment of superannuation for pensioners who are 55 years or older and who have received some income support payments for 39 weeks or more since they reached that age. Veterans with qualifying service can access an age service pension five years earlier than others in the community can draw age based income support. For male veterans, this means that they can obtain an age service pension from age 60. A lower age applies for female veterans—now nearly 55½ years. The pension age for women is gradually being increased to the same age as applies for male veterans; that is being done over a graduated period.

The superannuation of people who have reached pension age is currently included in the assessment of their service pension. If the veteran has not reached pension age, a service pension can be paid only if the veteran is permanently incapacitated for work. The new measure will apply to people who have ceased to participate in the work force and who have access to superannuation because they cannot work or have reached retirement age. For this reason, the superannuation held by pensioners aged 55 or more is to be included in the assessment of their income support payments.

It is reasonable and equitable that their superannuation is used for the purpose intended, and that public funds are not used to support those who choose not to draw down on moneys that have been set aside for use when they have retired or cannot work. If some pensioners cannot draw on their pension until a later age, the minister can determine that the new provisions do not apply.

In conclusion, this legislation under consideration offers significant support to the rehabilitation of Vietnam and younger veterans, greater administrative efficiencies and better targeting of income support payments. I reiterate my thanks to all those who have participated in the debate and also to the shadow minister for his co‐operation and assistance in ensuring the passage of this bill. As I said earlier, I know he will probably be moving an amendment in the House, but he generally supports the thrust of the bill. I do thank the opposition for their support in this matter.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J.A. Crosio)

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I put the question that the second reading be agreed to and call on the Clerk, I think we should have it on the record that this committee was set up for second readings, not to anticipate amendments or debates, with all due respects. I have granted the minister indulgence on this occasion, but it is a wind-up debate anticipating amendments that are going to be moved in another chamber. This committee is strictly set up to deal only with second readings. I have allowed indulgence on this occasion, but I do not think it is something that can be a precedent for the future.
