DEBATE.TITLE:
APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 3) 1996‐97 Cognate bills: APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 4) 1996‐97
APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL (No. 2) 1996‐97

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 26 February, on motion by Mr Jull:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johnston, Ricky, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —On Monday morning, I picked up a copy of the Australian , as I usually do, and I was surprised to read that the Labor Premier of New South Wales, Mr Bob Carr, was warning the federal government of a national health care crisis if the slump in private health insurance was to continue. The article quoted him as saying that the decline in private health cover was already swamping the public health care system and costing New South Wales public hospitals approximately $250 million a year. Mr Carr went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt falling rates of private health insurance have had a major impact on state hospital services.

These comments make me speculate that if Mr Carr had been in this House yesterday which side of the House would he have voted with. I am positive he is pleased this government's private health insurance measures were passed as this bill addresses many of Mr Carr's concerns.

Earlier, I had hoped to speak to the bill directly. However, I am glad for this opportunity during the appropriations debate to make some of the points that I feel very strongly about. As a health professional and someone who has had a long career in the health care area, I am well aware that we need to ensure that the private health care system remains an integral part of our health system.

I am a supporter of Medicare. Australia's system works well when compared to other nations' health care systems. Medicare, as a universal health care system, works reasonably well, but it is in decline. Our health care system is not working as well as it should nor as well as it can if the right changes are made and people are given greater incentives.

BREAK.PARA: In my electorate of Canning we have the situation where many people are continually waiting and queuing for available beds at the Armadale Kelmscott Public Hospital whilst at the nearby Gosnells Family Hospital, a private hospital, beds are often empty. I would suggest that that is a ludicrous situation. When the Treasurer (Mr Costello) handed down the first coalition budget in 13 years I was particularly pleased to hear that the government pledged to fulfil its pre‐election promise of private health insurance incentives.

The government has honoured its election commitment to make private health insurance more affordable for lower and middle income families. From 1 July this year, families with dependent children who already have or decide to take out private health insurance will be entitled to receive an incentive of up to $450 per year, which can either be an up-front reduction in their premiums or a tax rebate. This will make private health insurance more affordable for families. It will also have the added benefit of helping to reduce the upward pressure on the cost of private health insurance premiums.

In the budget, the government also delivered on its election commitment to fund a range of preventative health measures through our health throughout life program. The government has kept its election commitment to maintain Medicare in its entirety, including bulkbilling. However, if all Australians are to enjoy the benefits of high quality health care, it is vital that we re-establish a better balance between the public and private health care systems. The coalition believes that people should be encouraged to provide for themselves and their families through private cover. With people living to a greater age and technological improvements in the medical field, it is imperative that we change society's expectations about our health care system.

I was interested to read in the August 1996 edition of the Australian Health and Age Care Journal that repeated surveys have indicated that most Australians believe in user‐pays systems with a safety net provision, equitable access to community services and honesty from their elected representatives. It is imperative that we encourage people back into private health insurance because if we do not the future for our children looks very bleak indeed.
In the same edition of that journal, Mr Denis Hogg, the Chief Executive Officer of Epworth Private Hospital said:

The move by the government to reduce the burden of the cost of health insurance is the only positive initiative we have seen in this area for many years and we cannot afford to have it jeopardised in any way. The federal health minister wants to help boost insurance levels and we must do everything possible to support him.

I could not agree more. The latest health insurance figures, released earlier this month, showed that the continuing decline in the number of Australians with private health care reached for the first time below the figure of one-third of the community. This should be of grave concern to all players in the provision of health care services and force them to review their position.

The Productivity Commission's report on private health insurance is to be released very soon. I anticipate that the report will outline some practical solution which will help address the current situation, and to this end the government's legislation, which is now on its way to the Senate, is the first step.

Only last week I, together with the local state member for Southern River, Mrs Monica Holmes, met with representatives from the Gosnells Family Hospital in my electoral office in Canning. I also had discussions with people from the aged care sector about what priorities need to be addressed in planning for quality care for the elderly in both acute and long-term circumstances. I outlined to them in detail the proposed measures, and they all agreed without exception that the government is on the right track.

Of course, these measures alone will not solve all of our health care problems, and no-one is pretending that they will. However, we are taking real steps to ensure that the system improves. After one year of being in government, the coalition has done more to attract Australians to private health insurance than the Labor Party was ever able to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —All of two per cent.

—Health insurance should be like any other form of insurance: we insure our cars, and I am sure the member opposite does; we insure our homes, and I am sure he does that, too; and, of course, we insure our contents. So why should we not insure ourselves for health?

BREAK.PARA: I would like to put on the record my support for the government's strategy to increase the level of private health coverage by the introduction of a one per cent Medicare levy surcharge on those individuals who have taxable incomes above $50,000 per year. The levy surcharge will also apply to families with a combined income greater than $100,000 per year who do not have private health insurance. This means that a single person on $50,000 taxable income will pay an extra $500 per year through the Medicare levy and a family who earns $100,000 will pay an extra $1,000 per annum if they choose not to take out health care cover.

As I am talking about our health care system, I would like to make special mention of my concern about the gap. Some members may have seen an article in the Sunday Telegraph on 2 February this year which outlined the stories of two men who both had lifesaving bypass operations which were performed by the same surgeon in the same week. One gentleman had faithfully paid into his private health insurance fund for years; the other had opted out of private cover when he became a pensioner and could no longer afford it. The gentleman with private health insurance is now faced with a bill for $6,000, which he is paying off very slowly. The other gentleman received one bill for a post‐operative consultation for the princely sum of $9.80.

This story indeed brings home the realities of our health care system. Something must be done about the gap. People who are paying for private cover are doing the right thing. Some find paying for their health insurance a real financial struggle and others can easily afford to do so. But all of them rightly complain and feel outraged when they are hit with massive bills which they often are in no position to pay. This is simply wrong.

I listened with interest over the past few days as speaker after speaker from the opposition condemned private health insurance incentive legislation before this House. It was almost impossible to comprehend their hypocrisy. During the last election campaign, former Labor health minister Graham Richardson had this to say about private health insurance:
Unfortunately, Labor aren't recognising the big problem. It is still a huge problem . . . that people are deserting private health insurance at the rate they are. It isn't a problem any of you—
I suppose he was referring to Labor—
will worry about tomorrow, but in 10 years time it will be huge.
At least Graham Richardson recognised the problem, which is more than I can say for those Labor members who still have their heads in the sand, hoping it will all just go away.

The need to improve our health care system is urgent. If we left the system to the Labor Party, the system would by now be at the collapsing stage. Many elderly and aged pensioners have been frightened of what may happen if they became seriously ill. They ask themselves, `Will I get a hospital bed? Will I be treated immediately?' They worry that if they need elective surgery they may need to wait six or 12 months, or even longer. Their concern is very real indeed. Older Australians understand the need to insure for their health and they continue to take out private insurance which, in many cases, is a huge sacrifice for them to make.

The drift away from private health insurance has put extra demand on our public hospitals. One only has to visit one's local hospital to witness the chaotic situation, with people lying in beds in corridors, waiting for hours and hours to be seen by a doctor or nurse, who are often overworked and harassed but are always trying their best. It paints a picture of confusion, frustration and anarchy.

PARA.EMPHASIS: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—
Sitting suspended from 12.02 p.m. to 12.16 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Only last week an elderly constituent from my electorate of Canning told me of how her husband, who had undergone serious surgery, was sent home, in her opinion prematurely, because his bed was needed for someone else. This is not an uncommon story. It is not uncommon because the former Labor government allowed our health care system, which I believe was once the best in the world, to degenerate. Under the former Labor government, the proportion of Australians with private health insurance plummeted from 60 per cent to less than 35 per cent.

BREAK.PARA: This has put an unprecedented strain on the public health care system and has been accompanied by significant increases in the cost of private health insurance premiums. Despite the high cost of premiums, millions of Australians—many of whom are low income earners and pensioners—spend often considerable proportions of their incomes ensuring that they have a guaranteed hospital bed and the doctor of their choice.

Before the election, the coalition made a commitment to provide financial incentives to low and middle income families and individuals in recognition of the financial costs entailed in looking after their own health care needs. This budget delivers on that commitment. David Walsh, from Medibank Private, said last year in the Australian Health Law Bulletin volume 4 No. 10:

Despite some ideologically-driven views that there is no need for a private health sector, the simple economic reality is that Australian governments can no more afford to completely fund the health system than those same governments can afford to cover the costs of what constitutes private education.

The package of measures announced in the budget are a welcome start to mending our nation's health care system. We know that the system is overloaded and we know we need to encourage as many people as possible back into private health. People should have access to a full range of health care choices—both public and private. I am particularly pleased that the new health care measures will provide a genuine and real encouragement to those people seeking a choice, particularly those older and chronically ill people, many of whom are on pensions or low incomes, who scrimp and save to keep paying for their private cover.

PARA.EMPHASIS: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no doubt that good health is a precious commodity. The best way to ensure that all Australians have access to health care is by encouraging the use of both the private and the public systems. This government is helping the people that the Labor Party forgot during their 13 years in office.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McDougall, Graeme, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support these appropriation bills and wish to focus my attention on two specific areas: road transport and the Antarctic. I am sure I speak for all members when I say that I was delighted to see $148 million allocated to local government to improve sites with a history of dangerous accidents in all our electorates. But I was quickly brought back to the realities of Labor politics when I discovered that the Brisbane City Council, under the leadership of Labor, had attempted to use the program to recoup money for works already completed.

SPEECH.PARA: The black spot program is designed to give individuals in our community the chance to have a greater say in how road funding is spent. Yet Brisbane's Lord Mayor, Jim Soorley, forwarded applications for 15 black spot sites, knowing full well that half of them were not relevant. Seven of the Brisbane City Council's applications were for work that was already commenced or had been completed this financial year, totalling $1,289,400. Such nominations are beyond the intent and the spirit of the program and are tantamount to fraud.

As I said, of the 15 nominations presented by the Brisbane City Council for black spot funding, more than half did not meet the criteria. To me this is an indication that Jim Soorley and his team did not take the program seriously, nor did they do their homework, other than to make false and unethical claims. That Jim Soorley obviously did not see this program as a chance to improve the safety of the roads of our city is not just a sign of greedy politics but a slap in the face for the people of Brisbane.

The trauma alone which results from death or serious injury on our roads is immeasurable. In the next 20 years road trauma will become the second largest cause of loss of productive life, ahead of other causes like disease in the developing world. It is also extremely expensive in day‐to-day dollar terms. In 1995 there were 58 fatal accidents, and another 825 people were seriously injured in crashes in Brisbane city. The cost to the people of Brisbane of these tragic accidents is just under $140 million. We could build another hospital for that amount.

When we consider that this $140 million is for just one year, we see that road death and injury creates a massive economic loss to a local community. Every year the cost of accidents, death and injury on our roads could be used to build dozens of primary schools, child-care centres, nursing homes and other necessary community structures.

This government's effort to bring down the road toll is not just to save dollars but to improve the lifestyle of the community. The cost in human suffering can never be met. But a community suffers from road trauma both in dollars and in pain, therefore, improving our roads, recognising danger areas and expanding driver education are all part of the solution. Australia's record, while far too high, is much lower on a world scale, but it can always be improved.

Putting road safety directly into the hands of the community, as in the black spot program, is an innovative move. Its importance becomes even more relevant when we see how readily and quickly Jim Soorley and the Brisbane City Council responded. He nominated sites all right, but they had already been completed. He tried to redirect black spot funding to pay other bills. To me that is sneaky. It also smacks of arrogance.

The black spot program is part of the government's three‐pronged attack on road trauma: vehicle safety; driver education; and, finally, the hardware, that is, the construction and maintenance of suitable roads.

TALK.START.PARA: —A Labor program.

—And the Labor Party dropped black spot funding under Keating. Black spot is important because it gives the residents of my electorate and the people of Brisbane the chance to actively improve the safety of their streets.

BREAK.PARA: It is just a matter of filling in a form and sending it to the government's black spot consultative panel. As to those residents who feel that even this is difficult, I will fill in the forms for them and see they are handed over to the panel. I believe immediate action is necessary to ensure the people of my electorate have full advantage of the program and to bypass the greedy paws of Jim Soorley's Brisbane City Council. I move now to a completely different matter which comes under Appropriation Bill (No. 3), Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories. I refer to our specific presence in the Antarctic. As a member of the government's environment committee, I was able to visit the Antarctic during the summer break and inspect our three bases. I was accompanied by the director of the Antarctic division, Rex Moncur, who was able to answer all my questions in great detail.

I have reported to the government that I believe it is vital we maintain our strong presence in this remarkable region. To do this and to increase accessibility for our scientists, I believe we should construct an airstrip on one of our bases. You, Mr Deputy Speaker, as the member for Cowper this week called on the government to endorse the value of our Antarctic science programs.

I was not surprised to see that motion seconded by the member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones), who had ministerial responsibility for the region in the 1980s and has a great understanding of its value. Our scientific studies in the Antarctic are part of an ongoing international program. We share knowledge and skills, not to mention equipment and facilities, with scientific personnel from 41 nations which are members of the Antarctic Treaty. This research ranges from global environment issues, such as depletion of the ozone layer, to the study of movement of the Great Southern Ocean and, of course, the mysteries captured in the ice.

This pristine continent is in fact an instant environmental record, stretching back over 200,000 years. But only a dedicated core of scientists can afford to make the long and slow sea journey, and even fewer can stay for the winter months when the base is inaccessible to the rest of the world. An airstrip would allow a wider section of our scientific community quicker and easier access to the Antarctic and obviously would allow more time for their research.

The Australian scientific research team is currently involved in several scientific programs, working in collaboration with scientists from Norway, the United States, Canada, Chile and South Africa. It should go without saying that our continued non-political collaboration with other nations is just as important as the sharing of the results of the research. The strategic nature of Antarctica must also be considered when we look to funding our bases there. Many other nations are interested in the fate and future of this unique region.

The treaty stipulates that the region should forever be used exclusively for peaceful purposes. It also prohibits the introduction of any measures of a military nature. Mining is also prohibited. But while the treaty guarantees freedom of research and promotes the exchange of information, there is always the question of the region being opened up for other causes. Tourism is one area being discussed. To ensure we have a strong and permanent presence in this area to both protect it and our country in the future, I support any consideration for ongoing funding to our Antarctic division.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anthony, Larry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to speak on some of the major reforms that are happening in the sugar industry, particularly the implications those reforms will have in New South Wales. Before I go into some of the nuts and bolts of what the Queensland task force has recommended to the Queensland government, to the sugar industry and to the federal government, I think it is important that this House realises the significance of the sugar industry to New South Wales.

SPEECH.PARA: The industry is well over 100 years old. It was formed in the 1860s and has survived many changes. It is a vital industry in northern New South Wales, particularly in the electorate that I represent—Richmond. Over 1,300 families are directly involved with sugar production. Over 550 of those are independent landholders. Indeed, when you look at the multiplier effect, about 450 people are directly employed in the mills and over 400 people are directly involved in the harvesting operations and other auxiliary functions that the industry provides.

Today in New South Wales the industry has a direct value of $65 million. That makes it the biggest agricultural industry in our region. On conservative estimates, with a multiplier effect of about 3.4 times, we are really looking at an industry across the Tweed, Richmond and the Clarence valleys valued at around $200 million. So the industry is of particular importance to us.

I have to congratulate New South Wales cane growers—I am sure my colleagues here will be listening to that—because a number of years ago when CSR moved out of New South Wales, the growers got together and formed their own co‐operative and, in due course, actually built their own mill, in partnership with Manildra. This was particularly important because they went into the refined sugar market as opposed to being involved only in the bulk export of raw sugar. They had to do this to be competitive against the Queensland market, which produces over 95 per cent of the crop in Australia. I do believe there is a small amount now grown in Western Australia. Up to $45 million—a large investment—was spent in the late 1980s, early 1990s in upgrading that mill. It was very successful. They were able to compete and capture a lot of the domestic refined sugar market.

CSR actually closed one of their terminals in Sydney—probably for other reasons—so it gave that foundation to the New South Wales industry. They produce around 280,000 tonnes of sugar, of which 250,000 is refined and the other 80,000 is raw. We are very much the second cousin to our Queensland counterparts, although I would like to inform this House that we certainly produce much more higher quality sugar, particularly in the area I represent—the Tweed Valley.

The sugar industry in Queensland produces a crop of 37 million tonnes versus in New South Wales a crop of around 280,000 tonnes. The reason I am very concerned at the moment is that the recommendations of the task force, which have been pushed along by national competition policy—the precursor to which was the Hilmer reforms—will have a major impact on the sugar industry right across Australia, but particularly in New South Wales.

The package that was put together advocates three main recommendations. Firstly, it advocates that single desk selling be re-established. Single desk selling is not of much benefit to New South Wales because we are not part of the Queensland Sugar Corporation. Secondly, it advocates the retention of consignments. For those who do not know, consignments are where they have agreed quotas, let us say, for the growing to the mill stage—with the mills being owned by the Queensland Sugar Corporation. Thirdly, it advocates the removal of the tariff.

BREAK.PARA: In their wisdom, and in order to comply with national competition policy, the Queensland task force deemed it necessary to trade off one of the elements. They chose the tariff. The tariff does not have a significant effect in Queensland, except on those mills, particularly in North Queensland, which the member for Kennedy (Mr Katter) has been very vocal about. It has a major impact on New South Wales.

The removal of the tariff in New South Wales represents about $8 million to our industry. Because the bulk of the sugar in Queensland is exported—it is raw sugar not refined sugar—the removal of the tariff amounts to about $23 million. Some $8 million to an industry which produces five per cent of the nation's crop is far more significant than $23 million to an industry that produces 95 per cent of the nation's crop.

My concern is that the whole rationale for the reduction in tariffs under national competition policy is that the end result is lower consumer prices and that is why we are going through this. National competition policy has been good for the big end of town. It has been good for the electricity industry, it has been good for the gas industry and it has been good for big infrastructure projects, but I question its value when it comes to smaller communities and producing lower consumer prices.

Over the last couple of years in Queensland we have actually seen a proliferation of very large refineries established. Years ago CSR had the monopoly in Queensland. During the late 1990s there were legislative changes which meant that a number of mergers could not take place and a new mill was formed in Mackay. There was also a smaller mill formed in Bundaberg, which began in the early 1960s. Basically, it was a CSR market.

The Mackay mill did not have a market share so they began a discounting price war. Unfortunately, all major refineries are suffering huge losses as a result of this ludicrous policy of discounting prices to buy market share. I wonder whether one of the driving influences behind the recommendations of the Queensland task force is a great desire by some of the refineries to try to reduce their losses. Obviously, the clearest way to exit out of this situation is to do away with the tariff.

The tariff is applied on an import parity basis. Initially, it was there to stop cheap foreign imports being dumped in this country. The House should know that Australia is the most efficient producer of sugar and we do not have major subsidies. When you look at countries like Thailand, you find that they have subsidies for their sugar farmers of 104 per cent. If you look at the Europe, the EEC, you find there is a 170 per cent subsidy for sugar beet. The level playing field does not exist.

We are competitive, but there was a tariff. The embargo was taken off at the beginning of the 1990s. It is now down to $55 a tonne and with recent falls the price is about $38. My concern is that part of the agenda is to stop the huge bleeding that is going on in some of these mills. The other side, which is being advocated by the soft drink industry, is that by having a more competitive environment and no more tariffs it will result in lower consumer prices.

The member for Dawson (Mrs De‐Anne Kelly) in the parliament the other day drew to our attention what has happened to prices in respect of sugar, particularly in the two biggest areas that consume sugar—and we all like our soft drinks and chocolates. When you look at the ABS statistics from 1989 through to the last December quarter, you will see that there has been an increase of 52 per cent in the price of chocolate and an increase of 34.7 per cent for soft drinks and cordials.

This has occurred in a period when the tariff has been coming down and when the CPI has increased by only 29.5 per cent. So we are getting a far greater acceleration in prices which is outstripping inflation. Tariffs are being reduced, so the actual costs to the mills are reducing, yet prices are still rising. It begs the question: where are the profits being made? Of course, they are being made in the manufacturing sector. I stand here and say that I will eat my hat if I see the consumer prices of those commodities start to fall over the next couple of years.

TALK.START.PARA: —I've seen a few people eat their hats here.

—Perhaps it will be a chocolate hat. In New South Wales these reforms will have a major impact on our industry. The idea of removing the tariff is to make the industry more competitive and to have some rationalisation. As a member for a New South Wales electorate, I say that we will not be steamrolled by a task force that wishes to see the exit of one of the refineries. There are four refineries around Australia, and it will not be New South Wales or the partnership that New South Wales cane growers have with Manildra that will be steamrolled.

BREAK.PARA: The sugar industry is vital for our area. We are undergoing urban expansion. We have one of the highest unemployment rates in Australia and the highest in New South Wales. It is an old industry but one that we need to protect. What is good about the sugar industry is that it is a closed loop. Everything is used. Sugar goes in. The refined sugar comes out and the waste, which is a gas, can be put back through the mill or it can be trashed back on to the fields. Indeed, cane growers in New South Wales are being quite progressive. They have put boilers in, and I hope that in the not too distant future we will be able to connect into the grid and supply power. So it will be a total closed circuit.

The real point is that with the reduction of tariffs we in New South Wales are going to be worse off. It is going to affect New South Wales growers, and we will not be steamrolled on this issue. The bare minimum that is required is a package for the New South Wales industry. Discussions are going on now, and, of course, the first area to consider is infrastructure. We may have to get back into raw sugar production. Because there is so much competition with refined sugar, we may have to get back into the export industry.

I congratulate the mill because not so long ago it got a contract with the Singapore government to export about 20,000 tonnes. If we are going to get back into the export market, we need good infrastructure to survive. There are proposals for the port of Yamba, but maybe we need to think a bit more laterally about how to make it more efficient. At the moment there are new facilities at Fisherman Island, in the port of Brisbane. Obviously we may have to rely on that in the future to get more overseas markets. So we need infrastructure, and we need some money from the Commonwealth government for compensation in that area.

The second point is that we need to have access to the US market. There is a quota at the moment, and the Queensland government has had 100 per cent of it. It is a very lucrative market. At the moment raw sugar prices are about double in respect of the world prices. So, if we are to take that huge downside from these recommendations by the Queensland task force, we in New South Wales must have that US quota. I say to this parliament that we need more than our five per cent because we are taking a much bigger hit. I would think that eight per cent is a good starting point for a quota.

The third point relates to bulk terminals. When CSR was responsible for the mills in New South Wales, and for that matter across Australia, there was always a pool going into maintaining and building some of the big raw sugar terminals, which are allocated in Brisbane. Naturally, when CSR moved out of the New South Wales industry, we did not continue to pay for it. But it is estimated that from the time of the beginning of our industry through to 1989, when the partnership broke, $350 million was put into those bulk terminals. Five per cent of that, which represents five per cent of the crop, is $17½ million. So in future negotiations that the government has with the Queensland growers, I hope that there will be some recognition of the money that we put in there and that it will also come back to us.

The last point which I think this government needs to look at is that perhaps we need to see some rationalisation—which is not being forced by the tariff reduction—in the Queensland industry, perhaps through some of the takeover provisions which have prevented some of the major mills from coming together. Naturally, of course, there was Mackay and Tate and Lyle and CSR. If we could see some amalgamations, this discounting price war that we are getting at the moment would cease and prices would come back to the normal level.

At the end of the day, I fear that, along with the tariff reduction, it may send a signal to the buyers of refined sugar—the big confectionary companies or the big suppliers of sugar into products—that they have an excuse to force the price down even lower than $37 a tonne. The actual tariff at the moment does not really have a big impact when you are looking at overseas markets, because we are below that price. So if there is a reduction in consumer prices—I hope there is not, because we are efficient—I will be totally surprised.

There were some important meetings within the government last week and there will be more such meetings in future. The member for Page (Mr Causley), who is himself a sugar producer, has been very supportive of the industry, along with me. I do hope that an adequate package is put together for the New South Wales industry, for all those people involved. We must protect and encourage that industry. It is efficient. There are a lot of people involved in it. It is our biggest rural industry. I am sure that many Queensland colleagues within the coalition will be supporting us to ensure there is an adequate trade off if the tariff is to go. I question whether there was much merit in that task force in the first place, but I am sure that history will outline that. I conclude by saying that the New South Wales sugar industry is not going to be steamrolled by the Queensland task force. We want adequate compensation, and we are going to go hell for leather to get it.
Debate (on motion by Mr Sawford) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Securities Commission Investigators: Individuals Rights

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Campbell, Graeme, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 5 November 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Do Australian Securities Commission (ASC) investigators inform individuals of their rights under the Corporations Law; if not, why not.
(2) Do ASC investigators have express power of entry; if not, are individuals informed of this.

(3) Can ASC investigators alter forms; if not, has his attention been drawn to a notice to require the production of books issued by the Victorian Regional Office of the ASC on 10 December 1992 concerning the affairs of Safety ROPS (Aust) Pty Ltd, where the name of the addressee purportedly was altered by an investigator.
(4) Do ASC investigators have the same responsibilities and face the same penalties for tendering incomplete, altered or misleading information as do individuals.
(5) Is the ASC able to use evidence which it is found was obtained by inappropriate means.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am advised by the Australian Securities Commission (ASC) that ASC investigators do inform individuals of their rights under the Corporations Law.
(2) ASC investigators have the power to inspect company records at the company's registered office during normal business hours, and express power of entry when search warrants have been issued.

(3) Where an ASC investigator has drafted a compulsory notice and signed it as a delegate of the ASC, he or she may make appropriate changes to the identity and the address of the person upon whom the notice is to be served.

(4) ASC investigators are required to act honestly and professionally at all times in the exercise of their powers and the discharge of their duties. However, section 246 of the Australian Securities Commission Act 1989 provides that an ASC investigator acting in good faith in the performance of any delegated function or the exercise of any delegated power is not liable to an action or other proceeding for damages.
(5) The ASC is subject to the same rules of evidence relating to unlawfully or improperly obtained evidence as any other person. Such evidence may be ruled inadmissible by a Court.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Latham, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 21 November 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: Further to his answers to questions Nos. 578 (Hansard , 18 November 1996, page 6997) and 633 (Hansard , 18 November 1996, page 6999), does his Department prepare estimates of the impact of major Budget measures on private savings; if so, are these estimates then considered in the formulation of the Government's national savings strategy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: No, the Department does not prepare estimates of the impact of individual Budget measures on private savings. As noted in Question No. 578, the effect on private saving of individual Budget measures cannot be estimated with any degree of accuracy because of the difficulty of separating out the effect of other influences on private saving.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Filing, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 3 December 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Minister's attention been drawn to complaints concerning the poor quality of ABC television reception in the northern suburbs of Perth; if so, will the Minister initiate appropriate action to provide a satisfactory service.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Smith, Warwick, MP
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Sport, Territories and Local Government; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Sydney 2000 Games

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Yes. The National Transmission Agency, which is responsible for the terrestrial transmission of all national broadcasting services, has recently become aware of complaints suggesting a general deterioration in the reception of ABC Television in certain parts of northern Perth, particularly affecting a small number of residents in Ocean Reef and Gwelup. An investigation conducted by an NTA officer, between 9 and 13 December 1996, has found that the NTA's facility which transmits ABC Television from Bickley is operating properly, and that the signal levels for both ABC and SBS television in the areas concerned are normal.

The Agency has informed me that the perception that reception of ABC Television had deteriorated appears to stem from the poor siting and/or poor quality of domestic reception equipment in some households. In two cases, the source of a recent deterioration was, in fact, interference caused by domestic alarm systems installed in the houses of persons complaining about poor reception.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Treasury: Expenditure on Hire Car Costs for Ministerial Travel

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Laurie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 4 December 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: What were the hire car costs to the Minister's Department for ministerial travel between 1 March and 1 September (a) 1995 and (b) 1996.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: A search of the records indicates that there were no private hire car costs met by the department for ministerial travel. Costs associated with ministerial use of Commonwealth cars (COMCAR) for each financial year will continue to be published regularly by the Minister of Administrative Services.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lawrence, Carmen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 12 December 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When did the Minister approve the $100,000 allocated to the Bradman Museum Foundation.
(2) Did the Minister receive representations for the funds to be allocated; if so, (a) from whom and (b) when.
(3) Does the purpose of the grant comply with the guidelines for the three programs from which it is sourced.
(4) Are the three components of the grant the largest individual items in each of their respective programs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Smith, Warwick, MP
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Sport, Territories and Local Government; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Sydney 2000 Games

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Minister approved a grant of $100,000 to the Bradman Museum Foundation on 13 June 1996.

(a) Representations about a possible contribution were received from the Prime Minister's office on behalf of the Bradman Museum Foundation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Johnston, Ricky, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 12 December 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: Did the Minister's Department or instrumentalities under the Minister's control expend sums in 1995‐96 in the respect of (a) the Australian Antarctic Territory, (b) the Territory of Ashmore and Cartier Islands, (c) the Territory of Christmas Island, (d) the Territory of Cocos (Keeling) Islands, (e) the Coral Sea Islands Territory, (f) the Territory of Heard Island and McDonald Islands or (g) Norfolk Island; if so, what (a) sum was expended and (b) was the purpose of each expenditure.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: During the financial year 1995‐96, the Australian Bureau of Statistics made payments of $2,500 and $7,700 to field assistants/interpreters employed by the Australian Bureau of Statistics in the Cocos Keeling Islands and Christmas Island respectively. The staff were employed to assist in the undertaking of a Household Expenditure Survey.
